pros: If you get lucky and get on a good team, there are some wonderful people. I've been very lucky with the team I'm on and have a wonderful manager.
cons:
No room for advancement, not very diverse, not inclusive. You definitely have to "drink the Koolaid" and be popular to get anywhere in this company. They treat employees as numbers, not people. They only care about the bottom line. Massive COVID-19 layoff when the company stock was still performing well. They chose people at random to layoff rather than getting input from direct managers on who would be OK to cut. Micromanaging like crazy on some teams. Most management does not think you're working if they can't see you.
Advice to Management
Start treating your employees like human beings rather than numbers. Get with the century and technology and allow fully remote workers - it's cheaper for the company not to pay for giant buildings. Change your slogan - 5 years out does not represent the way you run your business.

review_title: I’m happy but I have never seen stability at Arrow. Layoffs are constant. Why in the office for Covid?
pros:
My job is good and I like working for Arrow. Great people work here, great managers. Insanely good infrastructure and tech. The building is nice and work life balance is superb!

I hope this turns around someday!
cons:
Seemingly zero opportunities for growth. I haven’t seen any kind of raise after several years and my teams profit margins even through Covid are up significantly. Layoffs are common and you will never feel safe. The bottom line is the almighty dollar so don’t think they value you.

If you’ve been with Arrow for 15 plus years you will be in line to get laid off first. No loyalty in anyway from what I have seen. Scary.....

Also why are we going into the office during a pandemic? Maybe trust your employees until they don’t deserve your trust and then make them come in? Idk. Just seems unnecessary.
Advice to Management
I want Arrow to be the place I can grow with but I think the entire work force is demoralized right now. I don’t know what the answers are but I would gladly change this review if things didn’t have sure a dire outlook. I’m scared to pursue a long term career with Arrow as it would be too risky to put all my eggs into this basket.

review_title: Extremely poor response to COVID-19 has highlighted the company’s weaknesses
pros: Proximity to I-25. Cafeteria and gym are adequate when open. HSA and 401K plans are decent.
cons:
Merit increases (which are effectively cost of living increases most years) did not happen in 2020 due to COVID-19 (as of July). However, employees are currently expected to come into the office every other week despite most if not all corporate jobs being doable remotely.

Management’s response from the beginning has essentially been reactive, requiring remote work only at the very last second when it was mandated by the Governor. It shows that they do not really care about employees’ well being. Profit > people.

In the handful of years during my employment, not once did we have a fire drill during working hours. Think about that for a second.
Advice to Management
Fix your culture, starting at the top.

pros: The cafeteria is convenient and they provide covered parking
cons:
As an experienced professional, I thought I knew the right questions for vetting a prospective employer, but clearly I missed the mark on this one. While most employers try to paint themselves in a positive light, it is only in retrospect that I understand just how severe and numerous the misrepresentations were at Arrow – from the recruiting process onward. Opacity seems to be the modus operandi and questionable business practices are so engrained in the culture, they have become normalized. Either the chief decision makers are woefully out of touch with the true culture of their Company or they simply don’t care. I tend to think it is the latter. 
To assist in the decision-making process for anyone thinking about accepting a position with Arrow Electronics, I’ve highlighted the main areas of frustration based on my experience. But in short, read and listen to the reviews – it is as bad as people indicate. The reviews aren’t just written by a few “bad apples” that are upset – there are numerous, deeply-rooted, systemic issues at Arrow that you should seriously consider before deciding to work here.

Misrepresentation #1: “Arrow is a Tech Company – we’re like Google” – Firstly, Arrow Electronics is not a Tech Company – their customers and vendors are Tech Companies, but Arrow is a supply chain manager. They ship electronic widgets from Point A to Point B – plain and simple. There is a small segment of their business that adds value to these electronic widgets but by and large the innovation is coming from the businesses Arrow contracts with, NOT Arrow. Publicly however, you may have been intrigued by the “5-Years Out” video distributed by HR or maybe you saw that commercial for the solar suitcase or the race car – nothing in those publications is representative of the day-to-day – merely marketing gimmicks. If you join Arrow thinking you’ll be part of this “innovation” or the general attitude that comes with innovative tech companies, you will be sorely mistaken. Which brings me to my next point…
In contrast, Google IS a Tech Company and their culture mirrors that. They’ve built a work environment that is flexible, empowers their employees to think outside the box, encourages them to think proactively and trusts them to pursue excellence in their respective fields. You will find NONE of these traits at Arrow. It is a stodgy, rigid, 1950s hierarchical organization that rewards blind adherence to orders from executives, lacks any sense of flexibility or openness to new ideas and one that actively discourages and retaliates against any who dare to buck the status quo. They rule with fear and control – threatening to take your job, smear your name, or sabotage your career. 
If you need just one example, take COVID-19. Google is flexible and caring enough to allow employees that can work from home to do so until at least the end of 2020. Arrow, on the other hand, tried to mandate a return to the office, while still under a shelter-in-place order. They’ve even gone so far as to disallow exceptions due to child care challenges or vulnerable individuals in the household. I’m sure vulnerable individuals will be mandated next.

Misrepresentation #2: “Diversity and Inclusion is Our Number One Priority” – Denver, Colorado is not exactly a diverse place to begin with but coupled with a complete and utter lack of concern for actually making a workplace diverse or inclusive, this statement is just laughable. For a Company that ranks this as their NUMBER ONE priority, you would think they might observe Martin Luther King Jr. Day or at least post some inspirational message on their social media about his contributions to diversity and equality. Nope. Or maybe recognize Autism Awareness Month? Cesar Chavez Day? Asian Pacific American Heritage Month? Pride Month? Nope, nope, nope and…..nope. Being diverse and inclusive encompasses a lot of territory, but apparently, Arrow has decided the better option is to just reject all forms or diversity and inclusivity.
And this is of course excluding the plethora of recent events (post-May 2020) which Arrow could have used to strengthen their stance on diversity and inclusion but instead they have chosen to remain silent. Deafening silence. Observing Juneteenth? Not Arrow. 
We get it – Arrow Electronics is a good ol’ boys club and you want to keep it that way. Just don’t slap some trendy buzz phrase out there that diversity and inclusion is a top priority because CLEARLY it isn’t.

Misrepresentation #3: “Ethics and Honesty are Core Values” – In my opinion, profit at any cost and haphazardness would be more accurate descriptors of Arrow’s “core values”. We take compliance training classes like every other place, but it’s window dressing. Without getting into specifics, the substantive actions of people in positions of authority, managers and above, blatantly demonstrate that their actions are not even remotely guided by ethical behavior or honesty. Their actions are guided by profit. And while some might argue that is true for most of Corporate America, I would ask you to stop and consider, when the last time someone at your job or in your career asked you to do something that was glaringly wrong? Something that made you morally uncomfortable and could result in serious consequences if these actions were to be made public? 
Of the many times that I’ve confronted my supervisor about this, I’m always given the same corporate puppetry lines that have been highly edited, filtered and polished so as to remain meaningless and opaque. Transparency and candor are foreign concepts at Arrow. To further compound this issue, is a perpetual desire to act before thinking plans through, which creates an endless series of confusion, ambiguity and an overall lack of personal accountability for pretty much every aspect of the business.
Advice to Management
Put the egos aside and be open to constructive criticism - the culture you project and the culture you THINK you have are not based in reality. Take an honest look at the reviews, pick something to fix and fix it. And be honest with your employees - people can see right through the "company line".
Helpful (30
advice_to_mgmt: Put the egos aside and be open to constructive criticism - the culture you project and the culture you THINK you have are not based in reality. Take an honest look at the reviews, pick something to fix and fix it. And be honest with your employees - people can see right through the "company line".

review_title: Arrow cares more about numbers than their employee’s Health
pros: The pay is decent, and I’ve gotten some good exposure, but that’s due to me being on a small team.
cons:
During the Coronavirus, we’ve seen tech companies all over giving their employees the ability to work remote until after the first of the year. These companies are changing the way they do things to protect the health and well-being of their staff. 

Arrow, from the very beginning, has cared more about the best interest of Arrow and nothing more. They attempted to force employees back into the office before the local stay at home was even lifted. This is rumored to have been shut down by the state. Ever since this crisis started, it’s been obvious what Arrow’s leadership actually cares about and it isn’t their staff.
Advice to Management
Make responsible decisions that better the health and well being of your staff. Follow the lead of the largest and most respected tech companies in the industry and don’t needlessly expose your staff just for the sake of having them in the building.

review_title: Arrow has finally lost my respect
pros: Great coworkers, just wish Arrow would appreciate the hard work they all do to line the executive pockets.
cons:
After many years in my current position, I’ve discovered my current salary is about the same as most entry level positions for similar jobs in the area. Probably my fault for sticking around so long. I take pride in my work, and feel loyalty to a company after expending so much time and energy doing the best job I can to maintain quality reporting and numbers. They nixed any merit increases this year, blaming it on the COVID crisis. But hey, at least we still have a job, right? It’s pathetic.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees, and stop the fear of retaliatory consequences. 

How about not requiring employees to come in to the office just to have warm bodies there, when most all have proven to be extremely efficient at working remote. Rumor has it that the major reason for forcing folks back to the office is simply because you’re concerned about having empty real estate. How about renting out office space that is currently needed, or does that go against the “Five Years Out” mantra?

Arrow really needs to re-think their whole work/life balance policies, times are changing, and you should want to outshine your competitors, but guess that isn’t what’s most important to management. Just continue to tick off the employees, hoping maybe they’ll continue to quit, and you can fill the positions with contractors. What a joke. Arrow has proven they have little regard for the resentment that a lot of the employees are harboring right now. 

If I’ve learned anything over the last couple of years, it’s that Arrow has, as someone else stated in previous reviews, become a company where excellent employees come to have their souls crushed.

review_title: The issues start at the top
pros: Easy to spell, also a noun
cons:
"Arrow Electronics Again Tops Industry Ranking in FORTUNE’s World’s Most Admired Companies List 2020"

Who are they surveying with this list, because it is certainly NOT anybody that works at Arrow.


For a company that moved its headquarters to Colorado in 2011 one would think the executive team would have addressed the massive increase in the cost of living in the state in the last nine years. That is not the case with Arrow. The corporate offices are in one of the most expensive states to live, and while executives are able to live here easily, regular employees are living paycheck to paycheck and working multiple jobs just to keep a roof over their head. Questions regarding this directly to the CFO have been met with uncomfortable laughter and the direction to go to HR. What may have been considered "competitive" pay 15 years ago is now entry level for this industry, even in the most rural parts of the country; yet is still being utilized company-wide. Calls and emails praising the company and employees for "record profits year over year" and massive seven-figure bonuses to the CEO and top executive team are mirrored with no raises and the thought of a bonus laughable to everyone below. 

But hey, you can wear jeans for an extra day next week, great work.

Even a standard cost of living raise is non-existent. While rent prices can so much as double year over year, salary remains stagnant. If you are one of the few who finds an internal promotion that somehow isn't a "lateral" movement in salary, the most you can expect to see is a 5% increase on average. Wage negotiation does not exist and is considered an insult to the hiring managers, you are offered what you are offered, take it or leave it.

If you live in the Denver Metro area you are guaranteed to have seen the Arrow logo somewhere. The money spent on advertising and marketing to establish brand recognition is astonishing, yet brand recognition does nothing if nobody knows what the company does. They are advertising a useless, unexplainable brand at the zoo, baseball and football games, Indy cars, etc. The common person does not shop at Arrow. The common person, if intrigued by the brand somewhere, will google the company and realize it means nothing to them, close their browser and move on with their life. The company is so focused on putting its name on everything that it fails to understand "Five Years Out" is a useless attempt at a buzz phrase that not even the executives can explain in ten words or less, much less non-employees even understand the meaning behind it.

Employees are expected to take mandatory ethics courses quarterly, oftentimes the courses themselves are amusing as you run through the examples of ethics violations and try to find one that you haven't been asked to do, or witnessed personally. Arrow may preach ethics standards, but they certainly do not practice it internally. "So-and-so said this needs to be done, get it done" usually with "so-and-so" being a VP or higher, we are expected to comply. Any questions are first met with assurance that it's ok because it came from VP so and so, that it will "be correct on the back-end", followed then by hostility. Managers and above have been known to retaliate against defiance, some even with records in HR stating employees feel retaliated against, but they remain employed as of the time I left. The fear of retaliation is so strong that many employees, in my experience, would rather proceed with questionable behavior than raise an issue among their direct management or within HR itself. HR is a resource to protect the company, not the employees. What used to be dedicated HR personnel is now a generic inbox. In my time I had no less than a dozen different HR contacts assigned to myself and my group, until the turnaround became so great a generic HRconnect email was created.


Not everything used to be like this. This used to be a fun company to work for, I used to be proud to say I worked for Arrow, one of Colorado's largest employers. Halloween used to be a very big deal, where the entire night before and day of was dedicated to groups decorating (oftentimes extremely elaborate - the pirate ship?) entire sections of the building to the point where it is unrecognizable as an office. Employees were heavily encouraged to bring their families and children through the buildings in the early afternoon to see the decorations and trick-or-treat through the cubicles and offices. It was something that everyone looked forward to. The last few years have been either "No decorations" or the day before "you can decorate if you like". No elaborate displays, very few children coming through, it has lost the magic and nobody at the top seems concerned to bring it back. Every year each department would have a large holiday party (think typical corporate event: Hotel, food, drinks, raffles... a fun holiday party where spouses were more than welcome). The only ones that are held anymore and strictly for executives, if any department wishes to do something it now comes from the pockets of the directors and middle management, nothing Arrow sponsored for the lesser employees exists. I don't know what is worse, being a more recent employee and never having experience the "fun" side of Arrow, or having experienced that and watching it devolve into a soulless corporate office over the last few years.

Arrow used to hold an extremely competitive benefits package. I guess it still does if you're an executive ($6,000,015 in equity awarded to the CEO last year). We had sabbaticals. We had stock provided to us after a year. We were part of the company. These were taken away without an explanation. Even the tenured employees weren't grandfathered in to the sabbatical program. Healthcare used to be decent, expensive but provided adequate coverage. Then around 2014 they switched to "high deductible" plans across the board. Now nobody I know of goes to the doctor unless they absolutely must. Nobody can afford to pay the monthly dues, on top of thousands of dollars for their deductible, just for their insurance to finally start chipping in. It's cheaper for Arrow though, bonus.



*********COVID-19 RESPONSE***********

I have seen a lot of reviews showing up after Arrow decided to show how much their employees matter in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. They are true. All of them. Given the choice, the CEO would have kept the offices open and at full capacity throughout this entire crisis. Luckily, 100% of the employees at the corporate offices have the capability to work remote, so when the state ordered offices to be temporarily shut down, Arrow had to comply. However production did not miss a beat, because of the aforementioned ability of remote working.

However.

As soon as the state order was to be lifted, emails were sent out saying employees are to return to work the day the order is lifted. Arrow Electronics is headquartered in Arapahoe County. Arapahoe County pushed the closure out another week, from May 11th to May 18th. Arrow was then self-declared an "essential business" (???) and therefore should not be held to the standards of the lockdown...even though, as stated before, all employees had been working remote the prior month and a half. The date of reopening Arrow was pushed out another week, most likely due to an order from the health department, and further measures were to be taken to ensure "employee safety and corporate compliance". May 18th, expected to have 50% of employees returned to the office, unless you had a medical or caretaking exception. On June 1st, those exceptions expired and any further exceptions became more strict. If you had a child with no school or summer care due to COVID-19 closures, that was no longer a reason for you not to be in the office. If you lived with people who were high risk, that was no longer a reason to work remote. Unless you had a signed doctor's note, on a specific form derived from Arrow, you had no excuse and must return to the office. Working remote was no longer to be an option every week; in compliance with the minimum state orders, the return was to be 50% of the time...every other week. Badges were to be scanned and monitored to ensure everyone had returned to the office. Everyone, that is, except for the executive team. Their top level floor is off limits to regular employees so nobody knows for sure if they have been in or not. Should probably monitor their badges too.

Arrow's competitor, Avnet? Their employees are continuing to work remotely through the rest of the year. Mouser? Working remote for the rest of the year. Digikey? Remote for the rest of the year.

Avnet cares about their employees and their community. Mouser cares about their employees and their community. Digikey cares about their employees and their community.

Arrow? A decade ago I would have said yes. A year ago I would have been able to trick myself into believing they do. This year? It's clear they do not.

As much as Arrow cares about their image, this would have been a prime opportunity to garner free publicity and good faith with the community and state as a whole. News stations eat it up when a large company treats its employees like humans. Flexibility during this crisis would have made a mention and interview on 9news. Now your employees are ticked and feel betrayed. You might not care if we quit, that's one less mediocre benefits package you have to pay, but we will carry this animosity with us for life.
Advice to Management
Focus less on brand awareness and trying to squeeze every dollar out of the company, and more on your employees that are actually making you these dollars.

review_title: Does not care about employees health & safety
pros: There are no pros to this company
cons:
Complete disregard for government guidelines and employee safety
Advice to Management
Arrow planned to open last week, however they were quickly shut down by the State Department because it was an unsafe environment - not because of the uproar that they heard from employees who were scared to go in. Despite orders by our governor that masks are required when you cannot guarantee employees remain 6 feet apart, Arrow is not requiring this. Arrow cannot guarantee that we remain 6 feet apart. We have many shared spaces like bathrooms, kitchens, elevators, stairwells, etc that are much smaller than a 6x6 space. Arrow now plans to open its offices on Monday, May 11th. I will wear a mask for the safety of my peers, but there is no requirement for them to do the same for me. As I'm writing, our Governor is holding a press conference and just stated, "There are no substitutions for people doing the right thing, wearing masks ... the more people that do the right thing, the sooner we can relax restrictions and the fewer people will die." Colorado Gov Polis. Apparently, Arrow is above the law.

Arrow doesn't care about the health and safety of its employees, or who dies. They're more concerned that their employees sit at their desks and dial into the same virtual meetings that they would dial into from home. My friends and peers in the Colorado area are not facing this with their employers. Instead, they leave it to the employee to determine what is or isn't safe for them. I am applying at many of these companies and I'd assume my peers are as well. I will leave Arrow as soon as I have another job, if they don't lay me off first. Don't get me started on the layoffs. 

Shame on you, Arrow. Shame on you.

review_title: Just a Job, No where nearly the company it used to be.
pros: Very few. There are many good people to work with, and compensation was above average.
cons:
People are treated as a number (headcount or $, you pick). Core values implemented years ago are not being followed by upper management. There is a severe lack of integrity. The Employee Performance Review is a joke. Your immediate manager rates you, but then the ratings are changed by others who have had no interaction with you throughout the year, just to keep within the acceptable range that was handed down from upper management. All perks that showed appreciation for the employees were stopped (Family BBQ, Holiday Party, Sabbatical, Tuition Reimbursement etc.). Wok/Life balance only exists for some, Others have lost many weeks of vacation due to the projects they were on and were unable to take time off.
Advice to Management
Get your heads out of the sand! Value your employees, they are your most important assets. Re-instate some core values and enforce them from the top on down. Integrity needs to be restored. Get rid of the bully management mentality and start treating all of your people with the respect that they deserve.

review_title: Arrow Digital, it's probably not for you
pros: Vanguard 401(k), unlimited vacation, parking garage.
cons:
The culture at Arrow Digital is about as toxic as it gets. If you're into whispering and gossiping, this is the place for you! Onsite benefits like workout facilities are pretty useless for some teams because other teammates are noticing if you're not at your desk and reporting the "unexcused absence" up the chain. This is encouraged by management. 

Arrow Digital Management is spinning its wheels, providing no strategic direction to the team, resulting in 3 rounds of layoffs during my short time with the digital organization. Their poor handling of their business is rewarded with bonuses and continued employment, while the people working long hours (without the possibility of a bonus) are watching their friends and co-workers leave without even being allowed to grab their coats on their way out. Arrow Digital understands at-will employment and eliminates jobs on the reg, providing a cushiony 3 day window for families to find new health insurance. 

I don't know much about Mike Long, but I would provide two thumbs down to the Chief Digital Officer & President, Matt Anderson. He built the site well from scratch, but hasn't been able to run the business successfully since. His leadership is defined by hiding in his office (across a major street from his team) and then screaming at individuals, often half his age, during meetings. The layoffs aren't his fault...it'll be your fault for joining his organization.
Advice to Management
Manage

July 3, 2019 – Director of Human Resources
Thank you for your service to Arrow and for your feedback about our Digital organization. We strive to build a culture which is engaging and encourages employees to thrive, and we're sorry that you didn't experience this while you were with us. We'll certainly use this feedback to drive improvements in our Employee Experience and we wish you well in your future
advice_to_mgmt: Manage

pros:
Decent salary
Used to be a fun place to work
Made some great friends along the way
cons:
This was a fun place to work a few years ago but after some bad hires and worse managerial moves, it has become a very toxic place to be. Sound technical decisions have been replaced by massive egos and mistake after mistake. It is really unfortunate because had they treated their employees like people, this could have been one of the great places to work. Instead, people are either being let go during a mass layoff or leaving on their own in search of a better culture where their experience and skills matter.
Advice to Management
Recognize the reasons as to why quality people are leaving and fix them. A few people making terrible decisions shouldn’t be able to destroy an entire organization. Get rid of them before it’s too late.

pros: Arrow offers a reasonable wage and raise structure. The benefits were also good.
cons:
Management did not care about their employees. My team was constantly under staffed and overwhelmed. This in turn led to more turnover on my team, which of course led to more stress being placed on the rest of us. There were several times that my team asked upper management to let us bring on more people, but we were routinely rejected. At best they would let us bring on one person, instead of the two or three the we needed. Ultimately, my entire team turned over twice in the year that I was at Arrow. That's nearly 20 people that came and left. Additionally, there was no formal training for my position. We were mainly left to rely on veteran members of the team for guidance. This led to excessive frustration between our clients and us, as they expected a standard of service that new, unexperienced, members of the team were unable to provide. Finally, since leaving Arrow, they have withheld my final paycheck for almost a month now. It has been nearly impossible to get a straight answer from anyone regarding why this has been happening, and the points of contact that they provided me with have largely ignored me.
Advice to Management
Clearly, all levels of ECS management need to change how they treat their employees; ideally this would be less like replaceable customer service cattle and more like human beings. I'm happy to hear that some people have enjoyed their time at Arrow, although I have never met anyone that felt that way.
Helpful (9)
Arrow Electronics Response
June 26, 2019 – HR Program Manager
We are sorry to hear this was your experience at Arrow. We will pass on this feedback to the relevant leaders. Additionally, we would like to help you get your final paycheck sorted out. Please contact us at HRCares@arrow.com
advice_to_mgmt: Clearly, all levels of ECS management need to change how they treat their employees; ideally this would be less like replaceable customer service cattle and more like human beings. I'm happy to hear that some people have enjoyed their time at Arrow, although I have never met anyone that felt that way.

stent hours and expectations for the most part

pros: Nice people although they didn't take time to get to know you in order to form any sort of relationship. No team building.
cons:
Absolutely no supervision by manager over staff. One employee did whatever she felt like even though it duplicated or changed other's work (including mine at one point.) Other co-workers said they couldn't do anything about this phenomenon as manager would not manage. I had absolutely nothing to do. There was zero planning on what my duties would be. Training consisted of reviewing videos and pdfs that were not applicable to the business unit I was in and were more of an overview rather than an actual demonstration of how to navigate system. I do not recommend accepting a job as a contractor at Arrow. I left a job I enjoyed because Arrow was willing to pay more and was supposedly contract to hire.

review_title: Not the Best Place to Work in Sales...
pros:
- Brand new beautiful building 
- Onsite gym with brand new equipment and group exercise classes offered 
 throughout the day.
- Arrow is doing amazing things around the world, it is exciting to be a part of it
-Lots of room for growth, and it's so huge it's great for networking
-They recently introduced unlimited paid time off and 6 week maternal AND 
 paternal leave.
-Arrow sponsors most of the professional sporting teams in Denver so there is 
 lots of opportunity for discounted tickets. 
-Lots of fun events to attend, and swag from professional sporting teams.
cons:
-Arrow is HUGE:
 *It is so big it is hard to find the right people to talk to.
 *IT is outsourced to India, if you have a problem you have to call India before 
 getting actual help.
 *You are just a number in a crowd. Upper management has no idea who you are 
 or what you do... nor do they really care.
-In sales they do everything they possibly can to avoid paying you your 
 Commission.
 *There is a 60/40 split for on target earnings. you have to hit 60% of your 
 assigned quota to even be paid out. 
 *No one can tell you how this quota is calculated.
 *It is almost always a struggle to get paid the correct amount, you have 
 to fight for it.
 *As mentioned above, finding the right person to help you get paid is difficult 
-When I was in inside sales I had an incredible manager but our team was 
 understaffed so there was no work life balance. There were no funds for the 
 team to hire anyone else so there was no end in sight and no support for an 
 awesome manager.
Advice to Management
Firstly, pay employees what they have worked hard for and earned. We shouldn't have to fight for what we have earned. Employees want to feel valuable, not like they are a number that can be replaced at any second.

pros: Get to wear jeans & I worked with some good people.
cons:
Wow, I don’t know where to start, so here goes. I worked Big 4 before I came to Arrow. I was told to ignore all of the negative postings & any other rumors that disparaged Arrow. Guess what, those awful rumors & stories were right. In fact they were spot on. If you are still an employee at Arrow, you will know exactly what I’m talking about. 5 years out, the biggest joke ever!!!!! What does that even mean??? No one knows. I worked with some (& the key word is some) people who are decent. The rest of you, not so much. How will you find out you are working for a bad company? Two words, month-end. Guess what, Arrow has hard deadlines, if you have to stay at work until 2 am, to close the month, guess what, you are staying at work until 2 am. Are you a parent, do you have other responsibilities like you have 2 of the worlds greatest dogs, you love like family? Doesn’t matter & don’t even think about checking on them on coming back. I put up with this for 2 years. The longest 2 years of my life. Vacation??? Ha yeah, try long-weekends. This is a company that rumors spread like wildfire. Sad. The constant threat of firings & lay-offs is like nothing else I have every experienced. This is also a company that loves to rely on temps. Nothing against temps, but the temps are held over the full-time employees as a threat. “You screw up, we have plenty of people that will gladly take your job”. FYI - most of the temps, never get converted to full-time status. Are you like me & you are thinking about coming over from Big 4, regional or local CPA firms? Don’t!!!!!! Don’t even think about it. You will thank me later. In fact run like heck & don’t look back. So many great companies would love & be lucky to have someone like you, but not this dumpster fire. I can go on and on. Read the negative reviews. They are all spot on. Who wrote the positive reviews? Seriously, do you even work for the company or are you in HR or marketing & were told to write them? Shame on you. Working at Arrow took a couple of years off my life. I’m convinced of that. Ask yourself this, why does Arrow have some of the lowest ratings on Glassdoor & some of the most dreadful reviews of any company? It’s because it’s an awful place to work.
Advice to Management
I find this question to be hysterical. I mean upper management loves to use cliches & key business words I’ve only ever heard while getting my MBA. Talk is cheap. Get rid of the bad employees instead of promoting them. When half a Department quits in one year, ask yourself why. Do a real employee survey & exit interviews. Read these negative reviews on Glassdoor & you will notice a consistency in the postings. If you truly want Arrow to be a great company, you can do it. Constant employee turnover is a real cost, relying on endless temp employees & using them as a threat, is a real cost. It’s not to late to save a once great company & it all starts at the top.

review_title: Be sure to research the company before applying
pros: Location, company is competitive in the industry, on-site cafeteria and gym. All employees have nice cubes. Pay is good, benefits are average
cons:
Management doesn't care about their employees , the work environment and culture is bad. Lacks teamwork, co-workers can be difficult to trust and many are unfriendly.. Poor systems and there are no documented processes to fall back on. Employees are treated like a number and easily replaceable. They preach employee appreciation, but its only lip service.

Improve management, encourage teamwork and better communications. Show more loyalty to your employees. Improve the systems, and reports. Promote a better work environment. Nothing worse than hearing about lay offs in the rumor mill. Improve communications, people enjoy being part of a good team,.

Nothing worse than hearing about lay offs in the rumor mill. Improve communications, people enjoy being part of a good team,.

pros: Some really great coworkers, but the good ones seem to be leaving in droves. Vacation time is also good if you have time to use it. The on-site gyms in the Denver offices are easy to access and have great equipment.
cons:
Company is in constant change with no clear direction from management from the C-Suite down. The motto should be updated to "One Quarter Out," but I think that's the clear understanding of most of the employees left. This used to be an amazing company that truly understood the value of it's employees and how to engage and promote employee satisfaction, but no more. Now it's very clear that executives and management here view employees as a highly disposable number.

-Bi-annual and quarterly layoffs 
-Layoffs aren't generally structure to target low-performers, just high-cost employees, so a lot of knowledge gets lost leading to high employee stress, more employee turnover, and poor performance when it comes to meeting customer expectations.
-People constantly leaving due to shear frustration
-Poor morale among employees, with many stressed and extremely overworked covering positions that are rarely intended to be back-filled.
-Poor middle-management
-Overworked senior management
-Absent executive management
-Constant workload issues leading to no life balance
-If you do have work/life balance, know that you'll probably be laid off and your position will be off-shored to a team in India. 
-HR team is useless
-Little upward mobility, with some lateral movement available.
-Promotion isn't generally based on merit, but more on who you know and how much you suck up.
-Don't expect a pay raise or annual increase
-Do expect constant re-orgs with less and less direction each time
-Working in sales, sometimes your commission check is right but more often than not it's way off in either direction. Sometimes they fix it though.

The list goes on and on but I think you get the picture.
Advice to Management
I think the Board should really look at where this company wants, clearly and openly define that direction for the workforce to align with, and to invest in resources (including management) to help get us there. If you ask us to jump for the moon but give us a management team that ties us to the ground, it doesn't work well for either party involved.
Helpful (20

pros:
Occasional work from home days; mind you you'll have to be actively monitoring your laptop the entire time.

On-Site café (Pro depending on the day and menu...)

Arrow is a Fortune brand; it's good resume fodder.

Pays slightly higher than average for Denver. Good thing too, otherwise they'd never have new hires.
cons:
Oh the things to say about Arrow, where to begin? Let's start with the basics: Arrow is not the company it was even five years ago. There are some things you can expect to see if you join this organization:

• An ingrained backwards-thinking middle management.
o Many of the managers in this company were hired as a result of mergers and acquisitions. They are ill-suited for managing in some cases, and ill-fit for managing organizations >200 employees in far more.

o Expect attitudes of “this is how we do it at Arrow” and “you can’t fight city hall” from this special group of individuals.


o CYA is the name of the game. Many of these managers want to keep their heads down as falling in line is occasionally rewarded, and risk-taking in any fashion is strictly punished. 

o HR consistently takes management’s side in any disputes. It’s part of the culture.


o If your manager doesn’t support a recommendation or idea you have, it dies on the table. You’ll then be called into a room and told your manager wanted that idea dead, because THEY feel the company has different needs. Even if they've chosen to take no action for years.

o Is your manager specialized in say Operations or Finance? Have they been successful in that role in the past? Expect their next step of advancement to be a complete change in discipline, and when they fail, it will be their employees’ fault. Managers frequently are unsuitable for roles they are placed in, which are “loosely related” to positions they’ve been successful in in the past.


o There is NO accountability. At least not in the traditional sense. If you upset your manager for any reason, no matter how unrelated to the job, you’ll be disciplined. But if IT doesn’t fix your issue for weeks at a time, your co-worker doesn’t feel like towing the company line, or someone’s favorite is involved (pretty much anyone in IT really), no action will be taken.

o Pray that your manager isn’t one of the many passive-aggressive types that have banded together to protect each other and hire more of their ilk. They are plentiful and problematic.


• A homogenous, fear-driven, defeated and uncreative IT team.

o Are you eager to show your innovative chops in an IT organization? Advance within a company to higher echelons of management? Help the business by providing world-class IT support and flexible, intelligent solutions? 

o Well, unless you’re male, middle-aged and East Indian, this is the WRONG company for you, because that makes up the majority of our IT. 


o Due to the above, female employees may experience exceptional challenges in our IT organization. On paper Arrow is diverse, in practice, …no. I’ve watched said Indian males (three times now) place their hand in front of women’s faces to say “stop”. HR action taken? Well, none of those women are still with Arrow now.

o If hired, expect to work long hours, while falsifying how long projects actually take (because projects have to come in “on budget”, even if the numbers used are pure fiction).


o You can also expect to work with a number of contractors. Arrow is on a perpetual hiring freeze (unannounced to most) in order to drive Operative Expense reporting on the P&L lower, to please K-Street.

o Expect to hear how we “don’t have resources” frequently. We don’t have them, but we sure as hell won’t hire them either!


o There are problems in direction and vision within IT leadership. What is said by senior-most leadership is not supported or followed throughout the entire organization. Act on the complaints you've received.

o Lessons learned at the end of the project: “1. We’ll look at the lessons learned next time.” Rinse, repeat. IT doesn’t learn from its mistakes, it commonly keeps coming up with new ways to make more.

o Changes will be made in the production system, either untested or not fully tested. In Arrow, IT pushing code "on-time" is more important than actually fixing the problem correctly. 

o Note on the above, it isn't the testing team's fault as development ignores testers when code fails test.

o Information is intentionally hidden from the business. How many hours will something take, when can it be started, how often is something happening, when will an issue be completely fixed? If there’s data, accountability can be created, so IT leaves all but senior executives in the dark.

o Did I mention IT works on what it wants, when it wants, and if the business tells it to do something differently, they refuse? The business works for IT, IT does NOT work for the business. Why? It's been stated it’s because IT knows better than the business does what the business needs.


• Disconnected and delusional senior management.

o On a recent web broadcast, the senior management team decided to explain a round of layoffs that took out many multi-decade employees as “We made a mistake. These are people we didn’t have jobs for and shouldn’t have filled positions. It was our error and we needed to do this to take responsibility for it.” Funny, the VP’s that made the decision are still employed, but a large number of line employees aren’t. Sounds like the employees, not the executives took responsibility for VP’s screw-ups to me.

o Expect on said web broadcasts to hear an hour-long string of buzz works and no real meat of what is actually being done in the organization. “Internet of Things”, “synergistic”, “solutions-based”, “five years out”…

o Everything is five years out, especially any budget being allocated to fix existing problems. Arrow is constantly moving forward, always without fixing and cleaning up after projects and initiatives it just finished or long ago implemented but never properly stood up. 


• And if you’re working in the business unit…
o Expect to frequently have systems go down or break, and to then spend days, weeks, months or years waiting on IT to get around to fixing it.

o Reporting? Use Excel, we’re “Five Years Out”, because that’s how long it takes before anyone in IT will even look at it. This is a running joke throughout the organization.

o New building in Centennial, several electric car docks outside, organization revenue was ~$24B last I checked; but we “don’t have the resources”.

o Only executive pet projects get approved or worked on, get used to it.


o IT to TELL you what the fix to a problem is, even if you know the customer/partner better than they do. IT gives you the fix IT wants to give, not what Arrow needs. 

o Only certain personally-preferred vendors and products are selected by IT. If your recommendation isn’t on that list, suddenly everything else is “too expensive”. Mind you, that never has to be backed up with research. It’ll just be called disqualified due to expense and you’ll be shouted down if you ask again.


• Some other things:
o During 2016-2017, the Employee Handbook was updated to remove all references to severance packages. No announcements were made of this change.

o During 2018, all employees are expected to go into the HR system and electronically acknowledge having read the Employee Handbook; multiple announcements were made regarding this change.


o Character assassination of employees who don’t drink the kool aid is a daily occurrence, eventually resulting in resignations or terminations. Just keep reminding yourself you were hired for your “previous experience and insights”. Arrow wants a variety of feedback, so long as it agrees with the agenda; and it had better!

o Little accountability at the lowest sales levels. If they don’t do their jobs, either managers or operational staff have to do it for them. Since there’s no accountability, the cycle of not doing their jobs continues on.


o IT systems go offline during work hours. Why? Because IT doesn’t want to work late of course…

o Expect security updates which only let you delay for 30 minutes to be pushed to your machine under the same logic.


o Need access to some program or secured folder? Access requests take days or weeks. Employees are not a priority, unless they’re Director or above.

o In 2018 Arrow announced a "payroll shift"; which amounted to stealing a full week of pay from every employee in the company, drastically increasing Arrow's cash flow at its employees' expense. Underhanded, unethically and while I suspect not necessarily illegal, it should be.
Advice to Management
Start holding your senior and middle-management accountable. The company is stagnant because too many senior executives have been in their positions and the company as a whole for far too long. Change starts from the top down, and while Arrow constantly preaches about innovation, you have stalwart status-quo executives holding the reins. 

Stop retaining burned or disgruntled talent from mergers and acquisitions. You have power-hungry middle-managers who are bent out of shape they used to be executives and now aren't. So they spend their waking hours taking it out on productive employees.

Fix your IT department. You KNOW these problems are there, you're ignoring them. Your entire employee base knows you're ignoring them. At this point, management looks foolish for allowing it to continue, the business is fed up with it (poll your middle managers and above about IT's performance across Arrow) and it needs to change.

Yes, your stock price continues to climb. It'll stop at some point if you continue on the current course. You aren't funding the initiatives which need attention, you're funding pet projects of various senior executives.

Remove every single micro-manager in the company. They have no place in the new millennial environment, or any organized corporate industry for that matter. They'll burn your interns and new employees, and that's if they don't cause your existing employees to quit first.

Stock sharing, tuition reimbursement, Christmas parties. Morale needs an improvement.

Fix the cement chemical leak in the Panorama parking structure. It's damaged multiple cars while Facilities dodges employees with damaged vehicles.

More stringent guidelines on discipline, you have managers abusing policies to punish people they don't like, not necessarily employees who did anything wrong professionally. That's why your turnover is an issue. 

I'd love to tell you all these things directly, but middle management loves firing (excuse me, "laying off") employees, and retaliation is a VERY real concern. I received your satisfaction survey a few months back. I lied through my teeth given that keeping my paycheck is far more important than you getting honest feedback through a traceable communications channel. Arrow is the kind of company right now that fires people instead of fixing legitimate problems.

And above all these things, back when I joined Arrow, I was excited to have been selected and proud to wear the logo. It took a single bad manager and a long string of operational and executive direction failures to get me to the point of posting this on GlassDoor. The next move is yours.
Helpful (38

review_title: Great colleagues & innovative company, but too many reorgs and no direction
pros: The new building in Denver is nice and modern with ammenities such as a gym and cafateria. There is an opportunity to work from home a few days a week and flexibility. There are many smart, kind and forward-thinking people that I worked with. There is opportunity to grow and learn. Innovative company with good value added services. Managers don't micro manage. I had weekly meeting with manager to discuss challenges. There are many great tools.
cons:
There is little direction from management. I was asked to do several time consuming projects. I spent so much time with little direction trying to accomplish my tasks. They would then decide not to move forward. I wasted so much time accomplishing almost nothing. There were several times where product managers quit, were fired or laid off and I was left to cover their jobs for many months with no extra pay. There are reorganizations all the time and people are constantly fearing they will lose their job. The company lays off hard working people that have been there many years. It feels like they don't care about or value their workers. This leads to poor morale.
Advice to Management
Keep the good people around and stop all of the re-orgs every year and then rehiring a few months later. This causes those that are left to look elsewhere. Provide more support and clear direction.

review_title: Strategic Account Development at Arrow Systems Integration Division.
pros: Great People to work with at the company. Substantial Opportunity working with the other divisions of Arrow Electronics on new technology including IOT.
cons:
Systems Integration Division is siloed and senior management lacks a cohesive Go-To-Market Strategy. Outside Sales is not aligned with either Inside Sales or Marketing.
Advice to Management
Short-term sales revenue approach by Senior Management.

Senior Management does not understand the significant value of Outside Sales, Inside Sales, and Marketing working together as one sales team. 
 
This is reflected by an individual sale approach vs. a focused and strategic long-term client account strategy to grow the business. 

The result of a lack of a focused go-to-market strategy and silo's leads to a lack of productivity for sales into both existing clients and new business development.

You have to re-inventing the wheel every time you need a customer reference, responding to a request for proposal etc. Which is a requirement for most large companies (multiple bids).

There is also a need to develop corporate relationships with Business Consulting Firms and large System Integrators like IBM Global Solutions, E&Y, Accenture, etc. as partners to grow market share in Fortune 500 /1000 accounts. They are already in major accounts helping to solve problems and develop corporate strategies.

Advice to Management
Focus on succession and development at lower levels in the organization. In a flat organization, experiential learning needs to be emphasized, discussed, and rewarded in addition to traditional upward movement. HR feels so disconnected from the business strategy, KPIs and requests are often received 2nd or 3rd hand without a channel to clarify leading to a slow response time and uncertainty if we've really delivered.

cons:

advice_to_mgmt: To the Board - Replace the CEO.

pros: Pays well. There’s a scooter. Denver is starting to be a tech hub so if you need to take a job at Arrow, something better will come along soon. They’re talent pool will continue to shrink as more and more companies move to Denver and treat their employees well.
cons:
Lay offs
No clear job roles (makes it easier to fire people when they have no job description)
The leadership is a boy’s club. There are token women to agree with the boys. If you don’t agree with the boys, you’re not in the club. 
Being laid off from Arrow is especially unpleasant because of the HR staff and their insensitivity and unfairness
All of the things that made the website fun and interesting have been removed. Creativity and innovation are not encouraged. 
You will think you are being gas-lighted all the time. And you are. 
Pay is good but the health benefits are terrible for how much the employee pays
Advice to Management
They don't take advice. Here are my comments. They have lay-offs almost quarterly. What they seem to like to do is hire a ton of people without defining their roles and then just lay off the people they actually never needed to hire. This is especially horrible for people who have left a steady job or relocated to work for Arrow. Had I known that the lay-offs were so frequent, I would have never taken the job. I saw the reviews here and asked about it during my interview but it was explained to me that the digital group is totally independent, they have tons of funding, they have a lot of work that needs to be done, and they are so cool and hip. 

If you define “hip” as having a ping pong table and a scooter in the office, then this is the place for you… for up to a year until they do lay-offs. It’s disheartening to see that even after this last round of lay-offs, they are still hiring for the same groups. They are either hiring the wrong people or they just don’t understand the value of a human. After working with some of the very talented people there, I believe it is the latter. I watched a lot of talented people be laid off when they could have either been moved into another position or just had better leadership. 

Women are treated like their ideas don’t matter. They are expected to behave in a demure manner so as not to hurt any of the fragile egos in the digital product and IT teams. They hired an e-commerce team with no e-commerce experience. Ego is so much a part of the culture, people get sensitive if they think you might be more knowledgeable. And then suddenly, you’re the problem for knowing what you’re doing and trying to do your job. 

I would say don’t even take the interview. They do pay well but it’s not a secure place to work. I can’t comment on the CEO but I will comment on the leadership for the digital group. They are spineless. They do not back up their own employees. They hire their buddies, both within the company and as vendors. The people who manage the vendors have no vote in the vendor selection so if their buddy happens to suck (and many do), you will end up looking like the problem as there is no loyalty.
Helpful (25

pros: The people. They are so dedicated to doing a great job - and despite some bad times, we worked together to stay on top. Challenges were thrown at us in every direction but the team stayed strong - a family. Such a family that when 1 round of layoffs happened years ago - people were so upset they quit themselves, or at least made management announce the names of the people who worked so hard for them yet were told not to come back.
cons:
Arrow doesn't care about it's employees. Don't apply. If you're thinking of applying, there is better employers out there.
Advice to Management
Advice to current employees - even those in Denver, do yourself a service and apply to a company that values their employees from all over the globe. There is a bigger picture, and Arrow has sent many good employees packing after years of amazing service to the company. People who, after decades of amazing service, were told OVER THE PHONE when their last day of employment would be. 
People who held on even though raises weren't happening and budgets were far beyond grasp. Someone pointed out that their "5 Years Out" program wasn't to achieve better in 5 years...it was a countdown to how many years left before you got laid off. I'm talking to you, current employees - management fails to listen, and everyone is replaceable. Get out and find an employer that will treat you (and all of it's employees) better.

review_title: Great place to work in Colorado
pros:
Arrow is a Global Company distributing value added electronics across the world. They are based in Englewood Colorado. They had started from humble beginnings and fought through hard times and are now the largest company of its kind.
18 years ago I was privileged enough to be apart of this growth and am proud to be apart of it. Great teams and co-workers made it what it is today.
cons:
Although in my department I still get to work with great people but the company as a whole is no longer the close knit company that I felt early in my career but that comes with the times and with growth. review_title: The work environment at Arrow as a FAE....
pros: Arrow, being a distributor of Electronic components, you will have access to most every manufacturer and exposure to leading-edge technology. If you choose to accept an applications engineering position at Arrow use it as a stepping-stone with the goal of learning the industry, and then move into a supplier FAE role where your talent and expertise will be greatly appreciated and rewarded.
cons:
Arrow is financial institution focused on sales numbers, not a engineering or design-driven establishment. It is all about sales and numbers and Wall Street, not engineering. They are 90% rules-based driven by metrics and as such reward mediocrity and conformance far more than innovation, competence, or performance and expertise in engineering. Negative reinforcement is the only incentive. It's a corporate culture from the top down based on bullying. If you are into sales you will be far better off than engineering, and will be regarded well better than applications engineers. My experience is they don't foster any career growth, there are few pay increases such that you won't even keep up with the cost of living. And as an applications engineer they will run you hot with the needle always pegged in the red and fail to recognize your accomplishments.
Advice to Management
Higher margins are what you are after with respect to engineering. So embrace what your engineers do for you. Let them engineer and design and promote sales through knowledge and technology. Keep FAEs out of admin, number tracking, and pure sales roles. Technology doubles at a rate of something less than every two years today. FAEs don't have time to be your handy-man or your clean-up crew like was the case many years ago. Your cheese has been moved. Evolve before you slip any farther behind. FAEs are there to get pre-sales print position, stay up with technology, stay up with products and new products, support customers and their designs by removing technical obstacles and pulling opportunities through the funnel to revenue while participating in the sales process from a technical perspective. Nothing more. That's how your suppliers use FAEs and if you are to succeed, you better get busy catching up and following suit. Every market will be different, so local empowerment is mandatory. And that means local management must be competent, motivated, have vision and ownership, coach, mentor, and support. What works in San Jose will not work in Wisconsin. Support, foster, recognize your FAEs skills and contributions at a corporate level and reward them, or resign yourselves to losing the talent you need most of all in lieu of a mediocre under-performing employee. Anyone in management from executive staff to the field that has been at Arrow more than five years needs to be re-trained or replaced. What you did five years ago won't work today. Your good stories and telling suppliers and employees alike what they want to hear, in spite of all your propaganda, is unsustainable and inappropriate in today's market. Either decide to make-good on all your engineering commitments and resource for it, or get your lack-luster website up-to-speed, resign yourself to declining margins, and prepare for E-commerce.
Helpful (6

review_title: Any true business professional should 2nd guess
pros: Still some great people there to work with and learn from their experiences. You can learn a lot about the overall complexities of business, and should make you more rounded as a business professional with someone else.
cons:
Execs continue to talk out of both sides of their mouths, and continue to choose to be disconnected from the business. Talking about how great we are doing in "town hall" meetings, then how bad we suck day-to-day. Talking about retaining and investing in our good people, then those good people are rewarded with no raise and more work. THEN on the flip side, the low-performers (who would be fired in any other company for constantly under performing) are rewarded with more work taken OFF their plate because they can't handle it! And they talk in these Town Halls about Talent Management when deep down their goal is natural attrition....and it's working because all of your High Performers are leaving.

Then they sign these $100-$200M deals bringing new suppliers on to do business with Arrow (and scream at us that we have to win with these guys; high visibility on this new supplier), yet they won't allow managers/directors to hire any extra head count to help manage these new lines.

The employee reviews are a complete waste of everyone's time. Raises are based on how the company does YoY, and not individual performance. You do an excellent job, congrats, you get a 3% raise. You do not meet expectations in your review, congratulations, you get a 3% raise. If you put in your notice, that's when they all of a sudden have 15%-20% to offer you.
Advice to Management
Understand your own business before you attempt to "lead" people. Nothing is worse to a team when the leader refuses to dig in and help. As for the execs, you are so disconnected to the actual business that nobody respects - and worse - believes anything said in these Go-Fight-Win meetings or emails that come out. You have a house of glass on the hill and see absolutely nothing wrong with it...and for everyone's sake, stop talking about the race car. If you are going to continue top funnel money into that, hide it like you do everything else where bottom line GP$ are wasted.

pros:
Worked for the Arrow Digital/Ecommerce:
- cool start-up feel and comes with perks
- free snacks and drinks
- open warehouse seating 
- collaboration and teamwork encouraged
- good benefits
cons:
Worked for the Arrow Digital/Ecommerce:
- poor management - direct manager had too much time to constantly micromanage, make poor managing decisions, provided very poor direction and could not simply answer questions, also believe that manager lacked the knowledge and skills to be in a leadership position so I'm pretty disappointed in Arrow for giving him a manager role - at least provide some training for new managers. 
- It seemed like the cool start up and relaxed environment was provided to only selective group of people whereas, my group's culture was more of a dictatorship brought on from my direct manager who was highly condescending, disrespectful, on a power trip, and extremely inflexible. all of this goes against their "cool hip" "startup" "laid back" culture. Direct manager used to ask me what type of appointments I had so he could tell me which type of PTO time I could use and I thought that was very invasive and would straight tell me to not even go to my appointments unless they were "extremely" important. If they weren't important, I wouldn't have bothered asking.
Advice to Management
If you're trying to make this whole Arrow Digital/Ecommerce large and actually trying to retain employees and keep them happy, please make sure the people you are choosing managers who have the knowledge and skillset to be in a leadership position. I cannot tell you how many times my entire team was so fed up with our direct manager's passive aggressive emails, remarks, lack of ability to provide any direction whatsoever, and lack of understanding towards situations. He insinuated that I was faking sick, lying, and threatened to terminate me. His constant poor attitude was adding to my stress levels and negatively impacting my ability to be productive. He has zero accountability and chooses favorites and seems like is bad at accepting a diverse workforce. So seems like he keeps hiring people that are recommended by the one or two employees he decides are his favorites.

pros: Arrow offers pretty stable employment and there are a few very knowledgable people in these departments to learn from. If your lucky enough to get one of these managers they usually realize there are better opportunities elsewhere. They offer generous PTO but you'll never find time to take vacation.
cons:
The managers at this company have a mindset that they've paid their dues and they are going to kick back. They make themselves look good on the work of their teams. While staff is working late you can find management taking off nice and early. Total double standard in terms of expectations. Expect your typical top heavy corporate culture here. Employees are miserable, unappreciated, underpaid, and overworked. Most people I have seen start at Arrow make it about 6 months. I have seen countless turnovers that result in consolidation of workload. This company believes a department already stretched thin can take two employees and turn the workload into one (but don't expect that consolidation to touch the manager level). Its not unheard of to work 8-9pm for extended periods of time. If you are reading this, take my advice and look elsewhere. You'll regret taking a job in either department. Arrow will promise you the world and probably even preach a "work-life" balance, it does not exist in the accounting or finance departments.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the dinosaurs that lead these departments. They have an old school leadership style that believes your career is built on paying your dues vs actual accomplishments and capabilities. Understand that the company has a disgusting reputation as an employer and in 2017 it just doesn't fly with employees.
Helpful (14
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of the dinosaurs that lead these departments. They have an old school leadership style that believes your career is built on paying your dues vs actual accomplishments and capabilities. Understand that the company has a disgusting reputation as an employer and in 2017 it just doesn't fly with employees.

pros: Arrow is an awesome place to make connections, cut your teeth on the electronics industry in general, and get a very broad base of experience as the company does practically everything under the sun.
cons:
Arrow is not a very rewarding company to work for. Specifically they have this corporate culture that doing your job, and doing it well, is not to be rewarded. If you do 100% of your job, that is considered average, and only people that are doing 150-200% are considered to be above average employees. They have no interest in taking an active role in perpetuating your career and expect the employee to be wholly responsible for pushing themselves forward. This seems like a minor complaint, but without guidance, mentorship, or any kind of positive reinforcement, this company really makes you feel like there is no way to move forward. Additionally; not giving employees a clear path to advance not only discourages them from working hard, but makes it nearly impossible to know or find out how to move forward.
Advice to Management
I know from working in other corporations that neglecting employees is a losing strategy. I have already seen the negative effects of this style management, with high turn-over and increasing disinterest in the company from incoming talent. For a company that is on the verge of losing a substantial swath of their workforce to retirement, the corporate culture needs to change to keep pace with the incoming workers who value a company that values them.

cons:
Upper management and executives do not value their hardworking employees. Very shaky job stability. And then executives will try to spin this in a positive way by displaying how low our operating income is compared to revenue. Still wondering who they were trying to impress with that display of information, I'm sure it was certainly not the Arrow grunts in the room.

Try to focus more resources on training and employee development. Having to rely on coworkers all the time is tiring.

pros:
Looks good on resume - Top Revenue in Colorado
Experience working with partners across the globe.
Company sponsors lots of teams around Denver, but employees don't get discounts for any of them.
cons:
The tagline "Five Years Out" refers to when the good things will happen.
Communication with VPs and lower level employees must go up and down the chain of command.
The health benefits can take up to 60 days to start, but they turn off on your last day at the company even though you paid premiums for the whole month.
The annual merit increases were 3+ months late, execs worked to find ways to drastically reduce the number of employees getting minimal 3% merit increases, no matter their performance.
Employees have no idea what the company actually does/produces, even though the Super Bowl commercial made it look like they use legos to fold paper airplanes. 
HR Leaders work below their level and don't trust their people hired for the jobs they are hired to do. 
The Executive Committee is not at all involved with their organization - they sits in a different building than 90% of the employees, referred to as the "Ivory Tower." 
Arrow doesn't value their employees, even though they keep talking about an “Employee Value Proposition” that is as nebulous as it sounds. 
There was an HR Reorganization that was done just to save money, and was communicated to employees that way, even though some of them were losing their jobs.
Helpful (15)

Many of the points you raise are under consideration, and I will make sure your feedback is presented to our recruiting team as well. We wish you all the best for your future endeavors

employee_status: Electronic Asset Disposition Technician in Sparks, NV
pros: It ought to be quite easy to be hired and it is not extremely difficult to remain employed. Many coworkers I respected had worked under far worse circumstances for less. The jobs are easy to learn and if a person makes numbers, other supposedly important criteria seem quite relaxed.
cons:
Massive turnover, clear management agenda to make jobs cookie-cutter with minimal education or training, drive to automate and cut down workforce--and yet a common reason for eliminating employees is mistakes in elaborate and changing processes while demanding and only rewarding high number output. Nor are employees who excel at that while performing with low error rates singled out for praise or advancement either. In general there are low opportunities for advancement, with arbitrary management that mandates a culture of "professionalism" that heavily emphasizes not questioning them, and a very long lag time between identification of major process problems and their eventual solution. They adopted the motto "Five Years Out" to complement themselves on their vision and forward-looking, proactive vision, but on the shot floor it seemed more of a statement of how long it would be before problems would be addressed. Everything driven by reaction rather than proactivity. Basically a dead end job and pays accordingly, with experienced and pro-active workforce driven out by low pay and low opportunities for improvement. Shows all the negatives of the legacy companies absorbed early in the decade which were understandable in such small companies, while driving out the committed talent that made those small firms viable and attractive purchases. Nor does top-down management distinguish itself by preparing for process changes they dictate in any way. This is left up to plant management and workers on site. This despite proud boasts by Arrow representatives upon acquisition of these legacy small companies that the large resources and deep pockets of a Fortune 500 company would mean better solutions to operational issues. In fact the supposed infrastructural resources of Arrow might show in a shiny workfloor and buffed walkways for visitors, but never in the machinery, hardware or software, we had to work with. If processes did improve it was from shop floor initiatives that never credited the workers who did them. Proactive vision was never in sight.
Advice to Management
If you lived up to your hype it would be an awesome workplace. Arrow Electronics has the deep pockets workforce to address your problems and you said so to legacy workforces drawn in when you absorbed their companies, but a high investment in proactive, thoughtful process design has never been evident in nearly 4 years I worked under your banner. Nor was diligence and excellence I observed in coworkers rewarded; instead these outstanding workers mostly left to find alternate employment before I did. I left a few behind I care about, but they would probably do best for themselves to get out in time. Only you managers can change this, and it requires courage and honesty on your part. Comparably poor conditions in other competitors, former and current, have the excuse of small companies striving to survive. If Arrow behaves the same way, you have no such excuses.
Helpful (9)
Arrow Electronics Response
August 26, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
Thank you for taking the time to share some feedback! It sounds like a major issue in your experience was a lack of advancement opportunities or training for diligent and excellent employees. It's unfortunate to hear that your experiences here were not ideal, and your feedback is valuable as we seek to improve our processes for all employees. We do wish you the best for your future endeavors
advice_to_mgmt: If you lived up to your hype it would be an awesome workplace. Arrow Electronics has the deep pockets workforce to address your problems and you said so to legacy workforces drawn in when you absorbed their companies, but a high investment in proactive, thoughtful process design has never been evident in nearly 4 years I worked under your banner. Nor was diligence and excellence I observed in coworkers rewarded; instead these outstanding workers mostly left to find alternate employment before I did. I left a few behind I care about, but they would probably do best for themselves to get out in time. Only you managers can change this, and it requires courage and honesty on your part. Comparably poor conditions in other competitors, former and current, have the excuse of small companies striving to survive. If Arrow behaves the same way, you have no such excuses.

pros: Arrow is one of the two largest Distributors in the Industrial Electronics Distribution Industry (Avnet is the other). They have a wonderful line-card (suppliers) and a very strong product and services offering. Given their position in the industry and product offerings, they can appeal to a very large target customer base. When a solid sales team is in place, they can move mountains. Many of the former leaders of this company were the best of the best. They groomed a culture that lasted decades.
cons:
There are virtually little to no traces left of this legacy culture. Most of the employees are either new and disgruntled or more tenured and disgruntled. HR became a revolving door, with little to no regard for the employee. Executive leadership who was tasked with managing this division, worked diligently to destroy any trace of the previous culture and instead worked to assimilate the culture to a more comfortable "Avnet", using the HR department and under-handed methods to rid themselves of these employees. There is little to no trace of strategic vision, except "the number".
Advice to Management
Senior Management should take a very serious look in the mirror and ask themselves what they are doing besides driving a number to make Arrow the clear number #1 and 5 years out. Managing a relatively disgruntled salesforce with little evidence of leadership, strategy, transparency or accountability is a sure recipe for disaster. For those who are managing this division; how you have overlooked an exodus of talented employees leaving the company, only to be followed by the HR manager's that did the dirty work of terminating them - is truly worthy of an internal investigation.
Helpful (7)

Although it seems like you are no longer with the company, we do wish you all the best for your future success(es)
