review_title: Good for a temporary job, bad if you want a career here
pros:
This review is based on experience from the OCS/ECS Integration Department in the Phoenix, AZ facility.

* The only way to get fired is to fail to clock-in ON TIME three times. Very difficult to do if you are a punctual person.
* They have 4 different shifts, but sometimes will try to accommodate you with a schedule that you need, but this is for rare cases only.
* Diverse workforce
cons:
* Very poor pay, very few raises if any (Integration Department) As an example, in 5 years doing virtually every job function on the production floor on both sides (OCS and ECS) as well as the warehouse, as well as troubleshooting, I have gotten a whopping $1.50 cent raise since first starting. BTW this isn't even based on performance, everyone gets a similar raise as a whole.
* They claim raises are based on performance, but that's BS.
* They don't hire/promote from within if you are in a lower position (Integration, Warehouse, etc.) I have tried numerous times to apply to different departments/positions, but never even get an interview, and when I follow up, they say they never got my application/resume.
* They don't hire competent workers, and ignore those who actually are and are trying to move up.
* The environment in the OCS department feels like high school and the workers feed into it by acting like teenagers. There seems to be low self-esteem problems.
* Very little communication between pretty much everyone. When there is communication happening, it is very difficult to interpret because they seem to lack basic grammar skills.
* No advancement opportunities if you already work there.
* Management never follows through with what they say and constantly change their minds about virtually everything.
* No tuition reimbursement, again they couldn't care less if you attend college or have certifications. But they are now requiring employees get A+ certified (which I have been since first starting) or they "demote you." Getting certified does not result in a raise. (I have many certifications, plus college education, and I am the lowest "tier" of their technician positions. I ask why and never receive an answer. Perfect example of management never following through.
* Most integration employees don't even know the basics of computer hardware and have 0 problem solving and critical thinking ability. AND are some of the laziest people I have ever seen, with the exception of a few people I can count on one hand.
Advice to Management
Stop being so greedy.
Helpful (10)
Arrow Electronics Response
August 29, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
Thank you so much for sharing your thoughts - it sounds like you have a good deal of experience on site and the payscale has not adjusted itself accordingly. Please know we are reviewing each and every one of our jobs and the duties within each job category to reach a better understanding of our employees skill sets as related to their day-to-day jobs. We hope to roll out some new changes within the year which will hopefully not only lead to a better understanding of people's jobs and what they do, but also, payscales and grades that each role falls into for compensation purposes
advice_to_mgmt: Stop being so greedy.

Etics are questinable. 
Managers speak like politician's. You are expected to know how the manager would handle an account, when management changes their mind daily. You must find a way to ship product regardless of the customers creditworthiness. Thus credit lines are increased for no reason other than to ship. Meanwhile management expects all accounts to be collected AT or BEFORE terms. 

Ship everything And have a percent current over 93%. Goals are unachievable, work load is beyond 40 hrs /week, but management does not allow overtime. At best Management is either clueless or simply inept. 

Income smoothing is a normal process. 

Management thrives on double talk and playing the hero to the GMs. They will tell you to delay shipping, knowing that Everything will ship at 5 and if sales calls they will ship the product. The lack of ability to hold a customer accountable has gone far that i have sales reps stating to hold a customer and we ship. 

You are a number. Corp does not care about the individual, we have a blizzard, 20 inches, and the company will not close. No holiday parties. No team events.

 Temps are training temps. Temps will not be hired full time for at least 12 months, I've seen longer.
Advice to Management
People are leaving the department left and right.... Look into this. 
The arrow alert line is a joke as retaliation occurs.

review_title: Employees are cattle - Reality Show atmosphere
pros: If you play the political game you're fine. You can have a long and stable career. Coming in you can even get almost market compensation and a benefits package. Once you're in, As a software engineer, I found that if you have no ambition to grow within your field, and don't mind working about four to seven years behind the times, you will be fine and have a long career on cruise control.
cons:
Pay is always below market - unless you're a new hire. Then they don't pay above market, they try to sell you on stability. It's a fear tactic. And honestly, there is no stability. If you kiss up to the right people, the right way, there is some stability. But make no mistake. Arrow does not profit from innovation. They profit from cost cutting. And you are nothing more than a line item on a budget. They would rather hold on to their (as I once heard a manager say) "Indentured Servants from India" who they VASTLY underpay and overwork, holding their work visas over their heads, than hold on to you. Even if you show you are highly skilled and prove your work ethic. They'll compliment you. But you will not be rewarded with market value compensation. Your new-hire offer will be the best your compensation does versus market value your entire tenure at Arrow.

As a developer, do not hope to introduce modern ideas anytime soon. Even external customer tools and web technology stacks are decided in favor of "one platform" which actually complicates what should be simple and keeps their talent working in technology and methodologies that are years behind. Do not expect to leave Arrow with a lot of market-valuable skills. Expect to find a transitional job where you can get back up to date first. Even contracting positions using the web technology stacks that ECS IT uses pays at about 75% of what the market bears for current web technology rates per hour. A great indicator: In 2010 the corporate standard browser was IE7. Until Microsoft officially ended support for IE7, Arrow refused to change until forced. IE8 was still the corporate standard browser in 2014!!!!! Until 2012, as a WEB developer, I was forbidden to install Firefox or Chrome on my computer without special permission and management from IT helpdesk.

Working in ECS IT is an absolutely morale-killing, career-damaging, innovation-vacuum. Management is in the business of keeping people in line and low-cost. The most talented people I was around were very unhappy but afraid that the economy made job-hopping out of something "secure" undoable (this is part of design - a lot of Arrow's message at company townhall meetings is one of Arrow keeping the world employed during tough times). Or they were talented people from India whose work visas held them to Arrow.
Advice to Management
"Our people are our most valuable asset" actually means something. Lend it some value instead of just lip service. And when you layoff hundreds of people, reduce benefits like tuition reimbursement, take away the sabbatical program, reduce the 401K match, DRASTICALLY reduce the quality of the health insurance offerings, require unpaid furloughs, and layoff hundreds of people, you make a statement. When the CEO and Chairman of the Board is asked at a townhall meeting whether the executives will take bonuses the year you do all of that and the answer is "Well, the economy tanked. We don't feel executives should be punished for a poor economy. So yes, the executives will take bonuses this year." What you are saying is that you will punish thousands and thousand (12,700 employees at the time) of employees and their families for the poor economy. Stop taking from employees and reward them. "Do more with less" and "Embrace change" are ridiculously transparent mottos.
Helpful (10

pros: Clean warehouse, large break room with lots of microwaves no waiting, free coffee, tea hot chocolate, feel safe and co workers are nice. Monthly meeting with both shift together to go over improvements, numbers, new projects, birthdays and anniversary's. Just started recognizing employees of the month. The Recruiter is pretty nice, when I had friends looking for a job she gets to them pretty quick or gives me information on openings. You get hired on through her and she is quick to reply to you either email or phone even after hours. GM is very friendly, easy to talk too and is in the warehouse a lot and not behind a desk.
cons:
Management team can be a little harsh on new employee, hence we have so much turnover, pay is very very low for our area. If the job was not so close to my home I would have left a long time ago. HR is a joke and treats you like a 3rd class citizen. It takes days or in some cases weeks for her to get back to you. I would rather spend my lunch on hold for 20 minutes than to work with HR about benefits, or even a problem on the floor. Parking lot is getting smaller as we have another location moving to this site, so make sure you have an umbrella and good shoes to walk in!
Advice to Management
Be more of a mentor to the new employees and work on training. If we had a better atmosphere on the floor we may cut back on turn over. Amazon is coming down the road and people are already planning on applying.

pros: Good company. Market changes having an impact on corporate strategy.
cons:
quently, the company will be forced to go through a transformation from traditional distribution revenue model. Arrow open to change but strategic decisions take too long to implement, sometimes "blindsiding" employees.
Cons
At the end of the day, Arrow ECS is simply a finance company. Partners may or may not have to utilize Arrow for their product acquisitions to sell to end users. Pre-sale services becoming less and less important to Partners. Appears compensation reduction strategy in effect as replacement employees are hired.
Advice to Management
Value experience and assist in keeping long-term employees. Good people are not disposable assets. Bring back ex-employees. Find new and innovative suppler lines and sign them more rapidly. Reduce expectations for GP dollars and GP percentage if supplier lines carry reduced overhead (non-inventory). Differentiate even more from competitors.

review_title: I have never been as unhappy working for a company as I have been here
pros:
Pay is usually above average
Large company so many departments and many places to work
The do cool things
cons:
They hire the worst of the worst for managers. I mean terrible. I have never seen so many unethical things in my career. No one reports it because retatilation is a thing here. A big thing. I've been here for 1.5 years and seen 3 people fired, 2 of which I thought were pretty good employees. No one was ever allowed to leave my department, we were all very miserable adn could not transfer out due to our manager not signing off on us applying to other departments. What sort of system is that??! I was told, word for word, "If I didn't like you, I'd make up some story and you'd be out the door". Good encouragement. Never once heard much encouragement, no word meant you were doing ok. Other groups seemed just as unhappy, though I know mine was particularly bad. We were told often we'd all be getting bad reviews, but it really meant nothing b/c when I got a stellar review I did not see any raise or bonus. 

Taking this job made my stress level go through the roof. There was never a good day. My co-workers would talk to me about how this job has made them drink more, be depressed and how they feared for their job often. The work environment was hostile and down right unethical. During close periods we would be in trouble if we took a lunch, as it was expected you did not take any breaks at all during that period. 

I asked for a vacation a year in advance with time off I had saved, and was told no b/c I was never allowed to be absent for more than 2 weeks at a time, even if I had the days (using floating holidays and pto days). That was unacceptable to me b/c I work to live not live to work. It was a year in advance. This should not have been an issue. 

I won't even get into the unethical things I was asked to do as an accountant in my group.
I used to think if I could just get into another group it'd be better, but from what I heard it was just as bad elsewhere. Not to mention, there was no way my manager would ever let me apply outside of my group.

I give a 2 on career opportunities because I was never able to utilize the many opportunities b/c my manager would also say something like, oh you won't like that job, or oh, we still need you so no I can't approve that right now.
Advice to Management
Do something about the hostile environment and HR infractions. Please please implement a review policy for the managers, though I suppose that may not be useful as most of us are afraid of retaliation. I witnessed a manager discussing other people's reviews to myself, (confidential), threats, and other things like it. I even saw a review (from the employee) that was rated low because they did not attend happy hours, which is illegal as ever.

Care for you employees. Bonuses are almost offered everywhere, not having them discourages employees. No raises is also a big no no when the company is still in growth year after year. We would get excited about new benefits supposedly being added, just to see them get cut before they even got a chance to be good (cafeteria, gym, sabbatical leave, more than 2 weeks of vacation can be accrued,etc).
Helpful (15)
Arrow Electronics Response
September 1, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
We really appreciate you taking the time to write us a review - we apologize that your experiences with your manager(s) has been a highly unpleasant one. It sounds like the particular group you are in is a hostile one.

We never want our employees to feel threatened, retaliated against, or unsafe within a toxic working environment - many of the situations you have raised seem to be a similar theme to what you've noticed others experiencing as well.
 
We'd highly encourage you to feel empowered to escalate as you see fit to address these concerns and get to the root of these issues
advice_to_mgmt:

As the largest IBM distributor; Arrow is not the company it used to be. A good company yet high sales pressure pushed and imbalance of accounts with the sales reps along with a struggling IBM has faded the glory. With two reductions in workforce over the last three years and a moving management that allowed for poor new managers and no leadership. The reduction left and added administrative processed added to the sales staff is over loading reps with processes instead time to so sell or service customer. Long hours are expected.
Advice to Management
The heavy workload caused by added responsibilities and processes and less people in addition to increased sales requirements on sales reps has gone on too long and expectations and requirements can be successfully handled with good wisdom. Get rid of a team lead that no one can meet the bar and has moved out or gotten over 7 people released. Everyone sees this issue except management.

August 29, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
Thanks for sharing your experiences at Arrow! There are great people in this company and many people with decades of experience who are a wealth of knowledge. We'd encourage you to tap into that! (Who knows, maybe you'll even make a new friend!

pros:
Great experience, good people to work with, you learn alot.
There are areas within the company that you can feel at home and work with great management who actually care about you.
cons:
The work pace and pressure is way too much for most people and there is very little balance and very little reward. Some focus on the pressure and some crack, if you choose to focus you end up with burnout periods and regrets. 
There are great deal of politics here and you need to stay quick on your feet to stick around for a long period of time. HR is a legal business here, they only serve to control the cattle exactly how management wants them to act and were to focus. If you have a concern about anything do not ever take it to HR, you will get fired if it even remotely smells like negativity. If you have a friend in HR keep things to yourself around them or you will get them and yourself fired.
They do not invest in their employees and do not care about this. Employees are numbers and as quickly as they get hired they get replaced to keep the big ship moving regardless of the emotional damage.
Advice to Management
Invest in your employees mental capacity and show genuine interest in them, their work life and their personal life. If you don't, the attrition will always be a problem your Cogs and Wheels will never make as much sense if you don't invest in people, not the business because the business will be greater and more profitable on its own if you invest in the people.
Take a close look at those who have been with the company for a long time, for those are the ones who have learned to play the politics and do just barely enough to survive under what can be considered a slave ship.

employee_status: Technology Product Specialist in Denver, CO
review_title: Bring the jobs back home from India!
pros: My commute was short as Arrow was close to home.
cons:
We had a company CEO prior to Mike Long who outsourced lots of jobs to India to a company called "Infosys". People in India make a fraction of what workers in the U.S. make and probably don't have health insurance so this saved Arrow lots of money. Therefore, the CEO and the board members got to stuff even more millions of dollars in their pockets as if they weren't making enough money already. This practice is extremely selfish considering the amount of money they make and the fact that all those employees had to find new jobs in a very sluggish economy. To add insult to injury we had to train our Indian replacements! They did give us a bonus for doing so, but that was a pittance compared to what this company was saving. If I were ever faced with that decision again I would get up and walk out. Why should we make it easy for these guys to destroy more jobs in the U.S.?

Our pay plan was changed just about every year to benefit the company. We were paid salary plus commission based on inventory turns and sales or "turns and earns". When sales fell off our commission was based heavier on sales thus netting less of an income. They were always messing with our commission portion with no explanation as to why, but everyone knew why.

There were very few women in management and the few who were chosen were less than desirable. It seemed as if the managers had little training in how to deal with people effectively.
Advice to Management
Bring the jobs back home to the U.S. where they're needed. How many millions of dollars are enough for you guys anyway?
Helpful (7)
Arrow Electronics Response
August 12, 2015 – Recruiting Program Lead
Thank you for taking the opportunity to write a review. We value the input of our employees and take to heart what you've shared about commission plans. It looks like you're no longer with the company, so best of luck with your future professional endeavors
advice_to_mgmt: Bring the jobs back home to the U.S. where they're needed. How many millions of dollars are enough for you guys anyway?

pros:
Financially stable company. They are trying to be future oriented, however they are going about it poorly. 3 weeks of vacation to start and moving to 4 weeks is nice.

Medical was good, now fair and if you have family coverage you are better off finding it elsewhere. Tuition assistance, was there now gone. Competition still has it as well as profit sharing.
cons:
Layers on layers of management, ever changing direction. PEMCO oh wait let's get rid of all of those people. Oh we need more feet on the street lets hire a bunch of ADR's. Nope to expensive they have to go as well. Oh wait we need more upper management. Management is the one group they won't get rid of.

Pay and commission plans, no raises after promised in town hall meetings but Arrow buys 2 more companies. Upper management gets raises and more stock options, but the sales people get nothing. If you bring the company $20 million in sales shouldn't you get a commission check? Maybe, but only if you grew your sales 20% year over year when you have 95% share in your accounts.

I forgot, Arrow Electronics is a distributor, there should be stock. Nope orders canceled everyday because you won't stock inventory or it gets sent to another customer because you don't hold parts to lead time.
Advice to Management
Think outside of your own pocket books and look at your employees. Remember without them bringing in the sales you wouldn't have a job. Pay people what they are worth, remember you aren't the only place in town. You see your employees leave for the competition but how often do you get people from them. If you do how long do they stay? You do surveys but nothing seems to come from them, you talk about human resources in notes here. Mine didn't know anything about benefits in the US because she worked in Canada...that's smart! HR doesn't seem to care about the employees either. The good ones have left for better opportunities.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Think outside of your own pocket books and look at your employees. Remember without them bringing in the sales you wouldn't have a job. Pay people what they are worth, remember you aren't the only place in town. You see your employees leave for the competition but how often do you get people from them. review_title: Finance/Accounting Read This Before Accepting Job!!!
pros: Room for advancement but you'll sell your soul for it
cons:
-Managers are so complacent and their lack of work ethic causes workload to be pushed to the staff
-When close comes around you will not see managers lending a hand but rather gossiping in one of their cubes
-No training, and its your fault you didn't ask for it
-Managers gossip about employees and are not shy about doing so, they'll also talk about employees to their "favorites"
-Managers seem to have unlimited vacation, even during close. Oddly enough its the end of the world and their job when a staff misses a close day (1 week every month)
-Rule out vacations for 1 week every month and 2 weeks every quarter end! Thats 16 weeks a year you do not DARE miss a day or you better believe you're going to have problems
-You will work late nights closes are generally 10PM and beyond, 1 AM + nights are certainly not unheard of and you must be there before 8AM the next day
-Job was similar to public accounting hours without the perks or career advancement
-Benefits are worthless... Count out retirement because there is a 5 year vesting period and you will not last that long the longest I saw was 3 years (trust me I know how much liability was released every year)
-Do not expect lunches, dinners, or anything extra to be provided by the company. Let me be clear there are no cool perks about working here
-No bonus
-No tuition reimbursement
-No stock options or purchase discount
-No free or discounted goods/services

Look at the number of job postings for Arrow accounting and finance jobs at any given time and that should tell you how much of a revolving door these departments are
Advice to Management
If you saw half of what I did from the ECS accounting managers and director at times you would be horrified. It would make a lot more sense why nobody ever sticks around and solve this great mystery. Your accounting managers are not leaders and they are cancer to your organization.
Helpful (20)

advice_to_mgmt: If you saw half of what I did from the ECS accounting managers and director at times you would be horrified. It would make a lot more sense why nobody ever sticks around and solve this great mystery. Your accounting managers are not leaders and they are cancer to your organization.

employee_status: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
review_title: No work/life balance. It's like being chained to a company. I thought Lincoln freed the slaves.
pros: Decent salary, but given the "real" hours that you spend on the job (taking your laptop home and logging in for 4 to 5 hours a night) I think my salary was much less than I am getting now.
cons:
Where do I begin....Branding our name???? I wonder how many people lost their jobs to pay for this foolish endeavor. This is one of the reasons I left. That and the fact that I had to log on every day after our 8:30 to 5:30 day. Seriously??? Guess what people, they just took away your lunch hour. Little things like that made me wonder if I made the right choice by joining them. After 8 years, I went to Cablevision and I couldn't be happier. A 9 to 5 job with no laptops!!! When I come home I can play ball with my son and not tell him "Sorry Daddy has to log on for a few minutes". Those minutes would turn into hours. No work/life balance. My advice to people would be to find another job. I did, and even though I'm making less money, it has made all the difference. ;)
Advice to Management
You're brilliant branding idea is not working. Stop wasting money. Get a new CEO. Paul Reilly is the only one with a real idea of what Arrow needs. He should be CEO, not a bouncer with a Bachelors degree??? I'm wondering if the marijuana laws were always in effect in Colorado when the board made this decision? FYI, I sold my Arrow stock as soon as I left and I making a killing on one of you competitors. See ya!

employee_status: Tool Crib Operations/Machine Operator Support and Records Management in Reno, NV
pros: I was very lucky to have great coworkers within my primary job duties and an excellent supervisor. I also enjoyed the input and support of most of my production floor leads.
cons:
The company is inflexible and pays a low standardized wage to all non-degreed employees. Its benefits are prohibitively expensive and they show no regard for exceptional employees nor make any attempt to retain them where they do not meet a minimum criteria for term of current employment. Management does acknowledge performance and achievement verbally, but is out of touch with the employee needs at the ground level and often makes promises it does not keep or fails to document what it has offered to an employee in the course of his/her employment thus causing a lot of its own problems in supporting and communicating the companies needs to them.
Advice to Management
I related my opinions to the company and have a very specific non disclosure in effect and so will not relate anything which appears critical of them or their practices, nor offer any further advice. They were not receptive to it and in fact the effort impacted me quite negatively due to new management in my department. They were unable to see the dynamics in play between me and the department and had a limited view and interest in the quality demonstrated by me in the performance of my duties. The scope of concerns they were brought in to address did not include my position or needs as an employee. They saw it best to label me a problem since they could not verify what their previous team had offered and felt that since it violated the HR guidelines for employee advancement there was no obligation to address it. They offered me no further recourse to resolve their own mistake.
Helpful (3

pros: Arrow is an enormous company with amazing opportunities at their Corporate office in Denver (Englewood). As a Product Manager, you get to experience a little bit of everything (sales, operations, customer service, inventory). The position is a very good launching point for something else internally if you choose to do so. You technically only need to be at your position a year before you apply for anything else, but I suggest you give it more time - 2 or 3 years - and become an expert in the industry/technology before moving up.
cons:
Very fast paced and demanding (although I'm the type that appreciates that aspect). Sometimes it can become monotonous, but honestly, name a job that isn't from time to time. The "training" is more of a baptism by fire, but your teammates understand this and are SO very helpful - and willing to help :-)
Advice to Management
Experience is definitely something to consider, but personalities and skill sets are too. Sometimes I think management rushes the hiring process to fill a gap, when it would be better to wait for a better team fit.

cons:
stently pays their bills. Reliable paycheck so far. Free plastic dining utensils (flatware) and coffee. Decent on-site security for theft prevention. Stand-up video games and web-surfing machines in the break room. We celebrate big achievements with on-site barbecues. Management choices seem to indicate they want to be better.
Cons
Most management (lower, middle, upper) are completely out of touch. A broken organizational chart and a bad living wage begin this review by a leadership professional. A stagnant culture and disrespectful-to-rude interpersonal relations between most management and other employees makes this a scary workplace: culture shock! A lack of leadership among managers has created a lot of disgruntled and unmotivated employees. This is number one of the two most hostile work environments I have experienced in my thirty years in the work force (twelve in the military); when an employee has to run off-site (during a shift) to get away from an unprofessional manager, then leadership is at an extreme low. Little investment in basic support: in three years at this Reno site, the corporation refuses to purchase basic tools, like brooms, to complete the work - employees do not dare ask for more advanced tools (screwdrivers.) Most employees repeat they are simply holding on until the close announcement. Atmosphere looks and feels like a prison or cattle yard with a metal turnstile employee entrance. Worst training ever experienced - I cannot answer myself when I ask how the training could be worse. Although, in fairness, I believe I have a very high standard for training (US Army); most companies fall short on my bar, but this is the nightmare, here. Senior leaders support and even encourage the bad behavior and choices despite suggestions: they know there are problems and want to be better, but do not know how.
Advice to Management
Invest in tools if you expect them to be used (even basic tools like brooms.) Bridge the gap between business management and managing employees; more specifically, get either some managers that have verifiable training and experience in Leadership Management or invest in Leadership Management training for the current managers. Most MBAs have a lengthy bad history from the perspective of Leadership Management: MBAs tend to focus on numbers and managing products / machines, but the MBA manager, and everyone below her/him, will consistently run into problems when trying to 'manage' people with the MBA-learned controls (impossible.) Leadership Management training comes from either extremely experienced managers or specific leader courses from the military. Think about it this way: any of our military branches could be considered a company where the company's product is people and the military company knows best how to 'manage' (lead) the product. I would also suggest: support our nation's military by hiring a trained and proven leader!
Helpful (4)
Arrow Electronics Response
September 19, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
Appreciate your highly comprehensive and detailed review - we do appreciate that. We are sorry to hear that the training here has not been adequate and that you and others feel you have not been provided the tools necessary to succeed. It sounds like the other issue is the leadership and managers here, and it's unfortunate to hear that this has been a frustrating experience as well. 

If you feel so inclined, we would encourage you to escalate to the appropriate party in getting your concerns resolved - that being said, thank you for your dedication to the company

pros: Company pays slightly above market average salary especially in IT department and for IT roles.
cons:
Company survives on thin margins. Couple of bad quarters for the company and you start worrying about your job. Company has 'Pay money and get the service' style and doesn't seem to believe in Asset creation be it Infrastructure and buildings or knowledge, internal capabilities and employees. Centralization is taking its toll on various business processes. Reporting structure is often irrelevant and team structure is often complex. Management style is top-down and there are no forums or meetings to listen to junior employees and ground workers. Workarounds thrive over solutions and quantity thrives over quality.
Advice to Management
Put managers in place of managers and not just deliverers who delivers the figures in the report the way senior would like to see. Encourage questions, discussions, problem solving and bottom up style of management. Build internal capabilities and focus on long term asset and value creation. Reduce the number of functional silos and align teams to business processes.

pros: Management is fair and personable. Flexible working hours - two days allowed to work from home. Benefits are average.
cons:
Low pay, annual layoffs, customers walk all over management & little room for advancement. There is a bad trend of moving in vendor outsiders into executive management positions.
Advice to Management
On paper I am certain your cost analysis and layoff policies work for the short term in this tough economy BUT, what about the future? You retain entirely too many older employees who are not interested in flexibility or advancing their skills and, let go of newer people who show promise. The bottom line is annual layoffs are indicative of poor management. The reason this company is seeing a rash of sub three-star reviews is because of that. This company is good for somebody just starting out in IT but, I wouldn't recommend it to a middle career person. If you want to attract some better talent, you need to change the business plan.

pros:
Flexibility, and can work from home 2 days (after a year)...co-workers are nice (mostly - there's always one or two who aren't team players)( ... but overall good working atmosphere....high cubicles, but not much privacy.
Maybe a good place to get your foot in the door in this industry --- but a cheap company with lack of focus on running it like a real company/corporation. At first it seems nice but then you start to experience the issues mentioned in the cons.
cons:
Cheap company: You will not get rich at Arrow. No raise in three years. I knew of at least three people who left the company in order to get a raise (one after 10 years, another 3 years). Only select few get a raise. 
Management : Some good some bad.. Buddy system and lack of training. My mgr was new and was terrible at listening, never took his team's side, and totally missed the boat ... when I was changed to another manager, he was great. The company also is not ran like a typical corporation. They have no support, no administrative support -- managers have a lot on them. Some try to help you and support you, but it's not good overall.
Training: Tthere is no central training or person -- and just poorl training all around. I was trained by another new employee who had been there 2 weeks! When I moved to a new area -- I had to lean on my co-workers to learn my new job. They were busy and didn't really have the time, but that is just the way it's done there. This goes for management as well. Really lacking! 
Commission Structure: They changed it ... If you meet your quota (which is all relative to your mgr and accounts - not really based on how hard you work).... by quarters. If you meet it and get paid the first month, and again in the second month - but fail to meet it at end of qtr (3rd month) -- you have to pay it all back to the company. Yikes! A veteran employee ended up having to do this -- and he said in all the years he had been there they had never had it set up this way.
HR: Lack of HR presence --- do not support or push advancement. No jobs are posted internally, and moved up if you know the right person. Closely involved with upper mgr, managers --- not so not going to be on your side.
Advice to Management
Pay your people. You have hired good, talented people -- really this is the one shining spot about Arrow -- but you don't pay them... and keep wanting them to do more and take more away. Restructure -- corporate policies and central training/person at each location. Focus on solutions versus blaming .... and when an issue arises internally in the office -- managers should not assume but welcome all sides to the table to discuss and resolve.
Helpful (1

review_title: Fortune 150 does not indicate they are the best
pros: Good brand name, great pay, overall corporation consistently profitable, and understands its core business.
cons:
Outside the core business it struggles with acquisitions and following a playbook through the mergers. Some of the purchased divisions are losing critical management talent while the business struggles to get on its feet. In 3 years time I saw massive turnover of staff within the divisions and the top management. At the parent level, it is impossible to get the simplest administrative task performed. Tons of red tape.
Advice to Management
Stop wasting your time thinking all the problems are with the systems. Most of the problems are caused from poor operational management. Figure out how to buy and merge small businesses successfully -- otherwise, stick to your core business.

review_title: Works if you can make it work you
pros: Possibility to telecommute, stable company, good salaries, and there some great, hardworking people there.
cons:
Your experience will depend on your direct boss. The company is so large that you can get lost if you aren't proactive. Also, the company doesn't invest much in education or perks unless you are in Sales. It's strictly no-frills--there aren't normal company functions i.e. an annual holiday party if you are into that sort of thing.
Advice to Management
Try a more progressive approach for company education and employee engagement. Arrow got rid of sabbaticals and tuition reimbursement, which is a shame. It's worth it to invest in loyal employees.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Try a more progressive approach for company education and employee engagement. Arrow got rid of sabbaticals and tuition reimbursement, which is a shame. It's worth it to invest in loyal employees.
Helpfu

pros: Interesting co-workers, stable job, paid the bills.
cons:
The managers were horrible. I saved the company $80,000 a year (at my location alone). They never even once thanked me, and did everything possible to make themselves look good as a result. I learned and trained my co-workers on a new system, including my managers and still had no appreciation expressed at all. It really made for an atmosphere that felt oppressive and unrewarding.
Advice to Management
Try to appreciate your people, especially when they are awesome at what they do. Attempt to not be so worried about looking good and inflating your own ego and focus on the benefit of the company, the working family, and those you are charged to manage.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Try to appreciate your people, especially when they are awesome at what they do. Attempt to not be so worried about looking good and inflating your own ego and focus on the benefit of the company, the working family, and those you are charged to manage.

pros: Good supplier lines and exposure to various interesting technologies. Fellow colleagues are great people to work with and are some of the best human beings out there. Great product training every 9 months.
cons:
Can be challenging to implement any long term strategies as directions can change very quickly quarter to quarter, month to month, and sometimes week to week. Health insurance benefit is very poor. Commission incentive is not linear and starts to cut in at a high percentage to plan. Moral is low with a sense of confusion. Process and metric can trump over actual results for political reasons.
Advice to Management
Don't get so caught up with getting the process and metric right, and stick your neck out and help solve a broken process/system when it doesn't make sense. Do less managing and help lead by example and get messy with the troops. It's easy to just execute on the higher-up directives, but you, the company, and the troops will be more successful if you do the right things. The trick is to figure out a way to do it without any one gettng hurt.
Helpfu

pros: They offer above average benefits and competitive pay.
cons:
The executive leadership is completely out of touch with its employees and reality. They are more concerned with the bottom line to impress their stock holders than they are on creating a better customer experience and for taking care of and rewarding their employees. They don't offer profit sharing or employee stock options and for a company this size to not invest in education reimbursement speaks volumes of their lack of foresight. For a company that preaches "innovation" and "5 years out" they show little to no preparation for a future with good employees. They do not reward, they do not promote, and they do not invest in their own talent. The culture there is "don't screw it up" and it shows. This company is completely broke of action consistent to what it touts it is. Go work for them if you want to believe in false promises and are happy staying in a stagnant thankless job.
Advice to Management
Layoff all of your senior management team Director level and up. Oh and go tighten your own belts! Maybe sell the two or three luxury import sedans you drive to work and give something back to your employees. If you're buying an AMG special order sedan and yet can't provide raises due to an "uncertain economic climate" then you're clearly cutting the bacon a little thicker on your plate than your employees. Truly a sad and pathetic company run by past middle age overweight white men who only look out for themselves. How about you stay true to your slogan of being Innovators and 5 years out...not Followers and 25 years back.
Helpful (15)

September 20, 2016 – Manager, Recruitment Systems & Operations
Thank you for your candid review of your experience at Arrow electronics - we're sorry to hear it sounds like your experiences here were not ideal. 

Many of the issues that you have discussed are under consideration, and one point it seems you are alluding to is compensation and taking care of our employees. One initiative we are excited about is an opportunity we have had lately to review our job profiles on site here and see what skills our workers have and the tasks they are doing on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis. This, in turn, we believe will allow managers to have conversations with their current workforce about movement, either upward or cross-functionally. 

As it's been close to two years since this review was written, we hope that your new role is treating you well, and wish you all the best for your future successes

pros: Good mission statement and the intentions are there to fulfill. Pro earth and recycling business motto. Great strides being made to minimize electronics and un-biodegradable items in landfills. Pay is OK once hired. Lots of overtime.
cons:
Mgmt is so overloaded and pressured they can't remain professional through the difficult times. Some in particular are very unprofessional, gossipy and have favorites. At the warehouse level life is OK but the fortune 500 policies allow for zero wiggle room, they are very aware that the job market is tough so they just fire people for anything. Policies of a large company dictate everything allowing no consideration on a personal basis. All decisions on everything from how the floor is laid to how the programs run for processing come from corporate with no employee input. Generally more worried about the big picture to care about the employees making it happen, just feigning concern to keep peace and in business. It is sad but In my experience the office is fend for yourself, don't wait for mgmt to help when you drown. This place is the mirror of the movie office space without the funny stapler guy. :(
Advice to Management
Corporate: get your head out of the sand, talk to the people in the warehouse. Production and money start there, they are the best ones to help grow the business.

General mgmt: represent your employees as a manager should. When a problem arises, discover the root before taking action. Make yourself available. Gossiping makes one untrustworthy.

review_title: Stable company, relaxed atmosphere, good place to start but no growth opportunity at all
pros: Work life balance is great, office culture is laid back. Ability to work from home. Company is very stable and has many lines of business across the world. Arrow is adding more to their line card and expanding their service offerings to partners. It will have sustained growth for the future.
cons:
Compensation structure is unlike any I have ever seen, there is minimum cut-ins and claw backs for sales reps. Pay is extremely low (paycheck to paycheck low) and doesn't get better even for top employees. 
There is absolutely no growth potential at all even for top employees.
Advice to Management
Put more focus on growth for employees if you want to keep top talent. 
Realize that well below average pay does not motivate employees. 
"Put employees first, customers second and stakeholders third, in the end everyone will be happy"
Helpfu

review_title: It's Who You Know Not What You Know
pros: First half of my career Arrow taught me a lot and challenged me strengthening my skills. I felt proud to be part of the team the first few years.
cons:
Downhill fast since 2009. Never seen so many layers of Directors and V. P. titles and less employees doing the hard work with no recognition . Leaders promoting inner circle leaders.
Advice to Management
Share the wealth of opportunity to all those that got you to the top. Stop using those hard working individuals as a step on your ladder. Promoting within is great as long as it's an opportunity for all not just the inner circle.

pros: Somewhat stable Fortune 500 company with decent benefits. Good customer and supplier base.
cons:

review_title: More of sales-focused organization than an innovative technology company
pros: I worked at Arrow for a graduate school internship. Overall, the company was competent, the hours are reasonable, and most coworkers are friendly, competent individuals. The focus of the organization is finance and sales though, not technology or innovation. So if you are looking for a sales job or a role as a financial analyst, this could be a great opportunity.
cons:
If you aren't in sales or finance, it becomes clear in the company culture that you are less important. Also, if you weren't an athlete at some point in college you probably won't get considered for any high-up position. The "Five Years Out" slogan is nothing more than a glossy multi-million dollar campaign from a New York Ad Agency, and certainly doesn't reflect the culture or philosophy of the organization. Arrow succeeds more on its vast scope of sales and operational efficiency than it does on innovation or moving technology forward. Many of the management philosophies and technology used within the company, especially workflow, marketing, and analytics software, are clearly dated, which doesn't seem to fit with a company pushing "innovation."
Helpfu

pros: You get to meet different people because the turn over rate is very, very, very, very high.
cons:
No pay raises. Cost of insurance is very high. Full time employees and temporary workers alike are treated very disrespectfully. You are told that if you don't do exactly as you are told you will get fired and you won't find another job because Arrow is the only one hiring. Workers are forced to work mandatory overtime everyday and Saturdays and are told there is no exemptions but the supervisor never stays or show up for the overtime. If an employee has an emergency they are denied permission to leave but if management has an emergency they leave no questions ask. If the employee leaves they are written up and warned that they will lose their job. This company knows the job market is bad so they take advantage of the people who work for them knowing that they will put up with almost anything to get their pay check on Friday. The company is constantly wasting money on useless things but the employees are given excuses after excuses about why they cannot get a raise. Moral is so low......
Advice to Management
It is time to wake up. Your employees are an essential part of the business. If they are not treated fairly you will lose every single one of them. It is sad that most of the employees that have been with the company for so long have resigned. You need employees there who knows the ins and out of the business to teach the newcomers how the job is done. Stop abusing your temporary workers! Word of mouth spreads and the word on the street is not good when this company's name is mentioned. A lot of workers are being abused and if they wise up and figure out how to log these instances and find out the correct agency to report their problems to this company would be in serious trouble.

review_title: Couldn't get out of there fast enough... Depressing!
pros: Very little flexibility with work shifting / working remote, etc -- but did allow a day here or there.
cons:
Compensation was poor, and promises were made to improve it that were never kept. Culture was poor, and most employees had bad attitudes showing that they hated being there. Depressing environment, created by a company that is being driven into the ground with no real future or way for things to get better. Even the office was depressing, with drab lighting, no windows, and a dungeon-like atmosphere. All the best employees left, and management wasn't able to attract or retain any good talent because of such poor compensation and benefits. Management was constantly looking over cube walls, and checking your computer screen to make sure you were "working" -- exercising nasty micromanagement techniques that are only seen at the worst companies to work for.
Advice to Management
Treat your employees right, keep promises made to them, and create a fun and exciting place to work.
Helpful (2)

advice_to_mgmt: Treat your employees right, keep promises made to them, and create a fun and exciting place to work.

review_title: A company in a state of chaos causing a ton of turnover and heartaches for those left behind.
pros: Global company with presence in almost 45 countries. Very flexible work schedule because they expect you to work from home every evening after you finish with the office hours. After all, this is why they give you a cell phone and a laptop so that you can be their slave. Oh and I you deal with the corporate office in Melville, NY, you will always be 2 hr late every morning because of the time zone differences.
cons:
The employee premium for benefits is expensive compared to other employers in the Denver Market. The company operates with one single objective in mind; how to maximize the cash flow and lower the cost of borrowing money to sustain a very very thin margin business!!! which ultimately results in zero annual raises, higher turnover rate, and pissed off suppliers because their terms are extended, to almost double, to meet the cash flow initiative. And they life to refer to the utter chaos as a fast pace environment... I will not recommend this company to anyone I care about because there is nothing called work-life balance in Arrow... Arrow operates with the principle of we hire people, we ride them to the ground, and when they give up, we replace them with new recruits.
Advice to Management
The company needs a new SLT (Senior Leadership Team) to look at the business structure without any unbiased views and without any regard to people who has been there for 20+ years because these folks are weighing the company down with their ancient views. The company needs a new CEO and CFO from outside Arrow so that they can evaluate what's best for the company and not what's best for the officers who had been there 20+ years
The company needs to consolidate all important functions in one city whether it is New York or Denver because the extra cost of maintaining 2 headquarters is huge and should be eliminated to move forward.
And What's up with the branding initiative? This is a very big mistake costing about $35M! Arrow plays in the shadows, why do we need to make ourselves more visible to Jane Doe who will never buy anything from Arrow! and to make it worse, the Five Year Out Slogan is only be understood by folks who live in North America... Other employees around the globe, where English is not their first language, cannot understand the slogan... what a waste of money!!!
Helpful (1

review_title: It went from fun to nowhere fast.
pros: Company well grounded in the distribution business and growing all the time. Benefits are good. Facilities are nice. Trying to make a household brand name for public recognition.
cons:
Management has strayed from recognizing their greatest asset...their people. Few avenues for advancement unless you know someone. Lateral moves available but no raise in pay. Has not been a pay raise in more than 5 years. Work is very tactical and redundant. Heavy work loads due to regular turnover and little effort to replace what is lost with quality hires. Very little team building and encouragement to work together. Just a come-and-punch-in-work-and-punch-out environment. There was not even the courtesy of an exit interview when I left after 9 years of service.
Advice to Management
Start paying and accepting your employees for what they are worth. Worry less about the bottom line and shareholder opinions and put more time and effort into appreciating the value of the workers who got the company to where it is today.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Start paying and accepting your employees for what they are worth. Worry less about the bottom line and shareholder opinions and put more time and effort into appreciating the value of the workers who got the company to where it is today.

Way too top heavy in VP's- how many you really need? Constantly lays off in the DC and programming depts. then rehires new temps as demand dictates. Loses trained people and again spends a fortune to late too train because the order volume already hit. Not interested in keeping trained experienced people during business downturn cycles. Hiring wage for entry level is too low for what is expected of people. Programming requires a different (higher) skill set than the DC operators...starting pay should be a buck higher. Theres Horrible order forecasting..................no method to check necessary equipment, supplies, and people before sales commits it to customer. Very little advancement possible in logistics..
Advice to Management

review_title: Satifying job, good benefits, and intellectually stimulating some of the time.
pros: The benefits are great. FAEs are treated very well, and are viewed highly within the company. They are rarely let go as they are the reason suppliers continue to invest with Arrow. The flexibility of the job is second to none, while the demands are reasonable.
cons:
There are few options to move within the company. The FAE role is more of a glorified sales engineer role these days. Very little in the way of offering true engineering support. FAEs are expected to act as conduits rather than subject matter experts.
Advice to Management
Stop treating FAEs like glorified sales engineers. The FAE role has been watered down, so much so, there are few within the company that can be considered engineers.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Stop treating FAEs like glorified sales engineers. The FAE role has been watered down, so much so, there are few within the company that can be considered engineers.

review_title: I worked there for over 10 years, didn't realize how stressed I was until I left.
pros: In my over 10 years of working at Arrow, I worked with many people that I have a great respect for. Some management willing to work with the employees to find a work life balance.
cons:
The benefits used to be exceptional and put Arrow above all other employers but over the years, the cost went up, coverage went down, lost tuition reimbursement, and lost sabbatical program. While some management is willing to work with employees, others (mostly the upper management ie directors) require salaried employees to get an unrealistic amount of work done in an unrealistic amount of time and has no problem coming in at 9 and leaving at 5 while their employees come in before 6am in the morning and leave after 10pm in the evening. Appreciation is rarely shown or communicated.
Advice to Management
be able to do what your team does. How can you review and "approve" the work your team does without knowing how the work is done? An employee likes to go to their manager for help and guidance but if the manager has no idea what doing the work entails, the employee is out on an island. Division presidents talk about a great culture, but the management does not encourage the cloture by example. Yes they talk a great game, but do not deliver in action or example.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: be able to do what your team does. How can you review and "approve" the work your team does without knowing how the work is done? An employee likes to go to their manager for help and guidance but if the manager has no idea what doing the work entails, the employee is out on an island. Division presidents talk about a great culture, but the management does not encourage the cloture by example. Yes they talk a great game, but do not deliver in action or example.

Advice to Management
Grow a pair. Don't fire people for having opinions. Don't assume that all Westerners are lazy bums because they disapprove of your management decisions. Don't freak out when laying off people and have security eyeball people as they get their things.

pros:
Arrow employees are the company's biggest asset
Average Salaries for the marketplace and economic situation
Flexibility to work from home when necessary
cons:
Technology needs a major upgrade to be competitive in the Global Marketplace
Heavy on the executive level light on the ground floor level 
Month end/quarter end extended hours without additional compensation
Workload unbalanced
Advice to Management
Get to know your employees in all the locations and buildings, cities and countries. The executive suites tend to be isolated from the workers and there is little to no face to face interactions with higher level directors and above. Invite guest speakers from other companies to speak about successes and failures in their organizations. Eliminate costs by restructuring employee reviews by talking with the employees to convey messages instead of spending a lot of money on additional time consuming online reading materials. Revisit the salary structures annually and compensate on performance instead of on a "meeting expectations" flat average line rating system.

Promote from within. There is a huge talent pool hungry for advancement with the experience and skills that will support the planned growth. You have some very incredible and amazing people. The growing Denver business marketplace has recognized this and is daily taking the talent away from the company by providing them with advanced opportunities they are not getting at Arrow.

pros: Arrow is not the Technology company I thought it was. Turns out Arrow is an old fashion warehousing, pick, pack, and ship operation with a questionable value proposition. Having said that, if your main concern is a paycheck, Arrow's compensation and benefits are surprisingly good for a company with declining margins. If you live in south Denver, the location is great. I'd also have to say that first line management is fairly strong and employee oriented. Its upper management that is disconnected.
cons:
Arrow is caught with an old fashion business model, declining margins, strong competition, and few ideas for the future beyond cost cutting. If you're looking to finish out a working career with decent pay - Arrow may work for you. If you're a young person looking for a career - look else where. This is a company focused solely on cost cutting and surrounded by more nimble and innovative competitors. Upper management places no more value on their employees than they would a copy machine.
Advice to Management
Consider listening to your employees. You might be surprised to find that they have some pretty good ideas for turning around declining market share, etc.

pros:

pros:
I observe, at Arrow, a ‘bottom-line’ corporate culture. The focus is always on the business statistics that control our stock valuation and cash-flow. In combination with Arrow’s compensation methodologies (ex. 70/30 base/incentive split salary) the individual employee is able to, with just a modicum of business acumen, directly affect their compensation and performance appraisals.
 This culture also, perhaps counter-intuitively, allows for certain freedoms an individual may not experience in another industry or even a direct competitor. One small example: As long as an employee is meeting and exceeding the business goals set for them their superior will, on average, allow a great deal of leeway regarding work times, punctuality, appointments and etcetera.
cons:
Arrow’s focus on business statistics can also be the corporation’s biggest con as well. Hard numbers don’t, usually, reward the ‘innovator’ employee. These employees may (and have been) cut in the rush to reduce operating expenses and increase productivity (output/labor-hour). Ironically, those are the types of employees that will help Arrow reach the goal of clear market leader most quickly and efficiently.
Advice to Management
Pay for, and retain, talent.
 We're just now feeling the backlash, across our industry, of the slashes that were made to workforces. Many companies drastically reduced their head-count in response to the financial downturn and in anticipation of a long-term decrease in demand. We’re now seeing the manufacturers struggle with diminished capacities and increases in demand. But most of them did not reduce any physical capacity so why are they having such difficulty ramping back up? Because they lost large chunks of talent and now how to re-train personnel!
 If Arrow is going to maintain momentum, increase efficiency and productivity, and reach ‘clear number one’ it can’t keep disposing of personnel to weather temporary crises.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt:
Pay for, and retain, talent.
 We're just now feeling the backlash, across our industry, of the slashes that were made to workforces. Many companies drastically reduced their head-count in response to the financial downturn and in anticipation of a long-term decrease in demand. We’re now seeing the manufacturers struggle with diminished capacities and increases in demand. But most of them did not reduce any physical capacity so why are they having such difficulty ramping back up? Because they lost large chunks of talent and now how to re-train personnel!
 If Arrow is going to maintain momentum, increase efficiency and productivity, and reach ‘clear number one’ it can’t keep disposing of personnel to weather temporary crises.

employee_status: Inside Sales Representative in Cleveland, OH
review_title: Be careful here - Management will barely appreciate your wins, and crucify you for your losses.
pros:
- Competitive Salary.
- Telecommute twice a week regularly, more if needed.
- Decent PTO offerings.
- Reimbursement of spending on personal sales and technical certifications.
- Ability to work independently, without direct supervision.
cons:
- Misguided, untrained management.
- Purposefully unattainable sales budgets and performance metrics.
- Lack of unification between sales teams.
- Management will not listen to or employ ideas form staff, even if they are worthwhile.
- No upwards movement or career advancement available.
- No training program.
- Lack of confidentiality within Human Resources.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees, they are the ones in the trenches every day, and they often know better ways to streamline a process. Invest in your employees. By not offering any type of training or career advancement, you are spending money on employees who will take their eventual talent to a competitor, which has now happened dozens of times.

review_title: When the market turns - I'm outta here!
pros: This is tough to come up with. The pay is good as are the benefits, although the benefits contract each year. Denver is a nice place to live.
cons:
The only plan management has to react to market share loss and declining profitability is cut, cut, cut. Lower level management treats employees well, but the CEO is a ranter and raver and that style is rubbing off on the rest of senior management. There is no leadership or long term plan.
Advice to Management
Other than to get a new CEO, I'm not sure what management can do. The longer term outlook for Arrow is not bright. employee_status: Field Applications Engineer in Wilmington, MA
pros:
A great place to develop your network with suppliers, customers and industry colleagues. At Arrow, field application engineers are exposed to a wide base of technology through interaction with colleagues, suppliers and customers. Take advantage of the many opportunities to gain professional experience.

There couldn't have been a better group of professionals that I worked with at Arrow. There was a team like atmosphere at this company.
cons:
Unfortunately, local management does not recognize the value and hard work of individuals. Many staffing decisions are based on the "Good ole Boy" network vs. the value that an individual brings to an organization. It does not appear that corporate sees this issue with their field management. So local and field managers are left to make decisions with really no accountability.

Bottom line, there is mistrust of management.

Arrow, like any company, is trying to maximize their profits. They have been localizing services in areas like Colorado. So a customer in Texas may get support from a center based in Colorado instead of local Texas support as was in the past. The result if this is a continued loss of local jobs.
Advice to Management
Show employees that you value their hard work. Try and provide some level of job security. Somehow try and win back their trust.

employee_status: Inside Sales Representative in Solon, OH
review_title: If We All Are Not Rowing in the Same Direction - Then We Are Getting Nowhere, but Doing it at a Record Pace
pros:
- it beats unemployment
- you enjoy taking work home with you
- you appreciate the subtle irony of being smarter than most of your bosses
- you like trying to figure out the archaic and ultimately useless compensation plan
- you enjoy watching friends and good co-workers get laid off despite your sales division making it's numbers
cons:
Ask any Arrow management type and they always harp on the fact that their strength is "their people". Yet, these are the same people they treat with flagrant disregard. "Their people" are overworked and underappreciated. Arrow has forgotten the rules of providing good customer service (which strangely enough was the driving force to some of their acquisitions). As a result, partners have noticed and are starting to leave in bunches. Guess what – that will be one more excuse for Arrow to downsize. Mike Long may eventually turn the company around (though I don’t know the man from the stapler that used to sit on my desk) but until they show signs of removing their heads from the sand I would not recommend anyone start a career there.
Advice to Management
Wake up - try and right the ship while you still have some good experienced folks to assist. Otherwise your talent will find positions elsewhere and Arrow will be left with the temps and short timers that they have come to rely on for their day to day work. Customers can tell who knows their stuff and who does not - trying to fool them with inexperienced workers is a recipe for disaster.

Also – you might want to try rethinking your customer service model. Sinking 150 million into a failed SAP project and then ramming it down everyone’s throat is a sure sign that management is out of touch with their workers and their customers.
Helpful (3)

Though it would seem that you are no longer with the company, we hope that your future endeavors are successful and pleasant experiences for you

review_title: Can be a good place to work - used to be a very good place to work
pros: Time/life balance good. Company is honest and ethical at least in my experience. Slightly above average opportunity for internal advancement - especially it seems if you are male. Friendly. Has new CEO who might make a difference.
cons:
Too many chiefs, too few indians. Few promotion opportunities for women especially to higher positions. Pay often below industry standard especially in Colorado. No raises, 2 week mandatory furlough, massive cuts to benefits this year, but then many corporations did that in this recession. But it was excessive at Arrow. Never was any bonuses except for Sales and Executive management. Totally different mentality between Melville, NY headquarters and Colorado. Colorado much better place to work. Melville behind times, inflexible, with a "not my job" attitude. Thinking for your self is not rewarded or encouraged, especially in Melville and it is huring the company. Company still has silo business mentality problem. Components division has no idea what other new, more profitable divisions do. Infighting for sales that really hurts the bottom line. Typical corporate problem of less than effective communication. Fails to provide employees with resources to do the job. Getting a lap top is next to impossible. Does not encourge working from home even a little. OLD STYLE THINKING IS THE BIGGEST PROBLEM and keeping people around who are no longer effective at their jobs, are you listening Melville? Moral is bad and has been for a long time. More often than not people get jobs here because of who they know in the upper circle, not how good they might be for the company. Old boy network is strongly intact at Arrow.
Advice to Management
Move everything in Melvile to Denver. Reward employees, not just the executives. Bring back the benefits. Promote more women. Give employees the resources to do their job. Stop playing to the market and stock will rise if you support your employees who will then work harder for you. Improve moral by offering bonuses for meeting goals.

employee_status: Inside Sales Representative in Marlborough, MA
review_title: If you are okay with staying in place, Arrow is a good place to work
pros:
(Note - Personal dissatisfaction comes more from the dissonance between my personal goals/ values and current job rather than Arrow itself) The best reasons to work at Arrow: The company is fiscally responsible and it's global. Overall it has done an excellent job cutting operating expenses and establishing practices to minimize loss and RIFs during the recession. The division I work for is financially profitable although sales are down year to year. 

Culture is not a "work overtime or else" --a 9 hour day is accepted and practiced. Pay is competitive. Older and youthful employees are valued. Somewhat diverse, but almost no cultural diversity. The office I work in is a fairly laid back place to work, with a New England aggression/superiority overlay. It's a cliquish but not malicious group. Management is pretty honest, earnest, and means well.
cons:
(Preface -- much personal dissatisfaction comes more from the dissonance between my personal goals/ values and current job, rather than Arrow itself). 

Extremely difficult to develop or advance. If you are okay with staying in place, Arrow is a good, stable place to work. Personal Development plans are pure pro forma. Arrow University is a joke. Online development tools are not explained or used well. Management measures performance metrics by how your peers perceive you, so ERP is a bit of a popularity contest. If you're capable but not popular you get low marks. 

How well you do in a customer satisfaction crisis counts, which often means that customers must become dissatisfied before your performance can be appreciated. Sor the bar ends up staying fairly low. Other than that there are no formal performance monitoring metrics. Tuition assistance and sabbaticals have been suspended. 

The division I work for was originally high touch. It has flattened out and dumbed down over the years. Sales emphasis is low, order accuracy and service levels are high. Lots of focus around workarounds to existing processes that don't work so well, so there are lots of complex trees branching out from somewhat dysfunctional processes. Teams work around processes or execute real time customer product/inventory inquiries. You feed the job in the limited capacity it requires, the job doesn't feed you nor does it require any creative energy. For a right brainer, It can be an energy drain with few moments of inspiration. 

Not a lot of strategic or visionary thinking/planning at the staff/group level. When it happens at management level it doesn't get communicated very well if at all. Communication from the top down and laterally has been and continues to be broken with a lot of lip service given to fixing it. Tasks are repetitive. I hear the frustration all around me and it can bleed out to customers.
Advice to Management
When you say that staff is the strongest resource and do nothing to help us maintain our strength and passion, it's just lip service. Say it and commit to feeding that resource. People need to be passionate about something other than a good salary to bring them to work every day. Passion, determiniation and excitement rather than frustration and no can do is what customers like. 

Make divisions less silo'd. Establish some P&L measurement connection between different groups that both face the customer. Regarding Bill Mitchell approval below, as of May 1st, 2009 he is no longer CEO. Mike Long took over the position. Mitchell did an excellent job, one exception being Lean 6 Sigma - it wasn't a strong imprint (weak rollout) - as a result the natives who were supposed to be converted are still practicing the Voodoo.

Be more communicative about the industry changes that affect the company - Sun/Oracle, shrinking HP, IBM, etc.
Helpful (3

pros: In this unstable economy, having a job is a big plus, period. Salaried and benefits are as good as most Fortune 500's. I would agree with an earlier commentator that lower levels of management are employee oriented and fair.
cons:
Unstable, confused strategy, lack of a clear value proposition, questionable senior management, worsening market position. It seems that every time Arrow takes another hit in the market, management resorts to knee-jerk layoffs. Freezing salaries in this market is probably not unreasonable, but laying off valuable contributers is.
Advice to Management
Don't make cost cutting and layoffs your only strategy. Recognize that the margins of the past aren't coming back.

Recognize and compensate your top employees. Don't let your best employees leave for other companies because they're missing opportunities at Arrow. Don't be afraid to let well educated and business savy people speak up. I find that many of the positions at Arrow require a HS diploma plus experience. Many of these positions would be justified in requiring a bachelors degree and as such, you could solicit higher qualified employees for the future.

There is no real structure in the way of career advancement (From what I've seen, if you're a minority you have very, very little chance of moving up), and management simply doesn't care about the work/life balance (Overtime is not simply suggested, it's required - especially at quarter/year end). A good percentage of management are unqualified for the positions they hold, and some of them have less education than the people they are manage. The best employees eventually get tired of this and end up going to other companies (including our competitors). And because of the downturn, we've recently lost a lot of people, which makes it that much harder for everyone around the office to do their job.
Advice to Management
Do your best to keep quality people here.

Firstly, thank you so much for your dedication to the company all of these years - we do appreciate it! It's great to see you highlighting the strengths of the organization, and appreciate you noticing areas from improvement. It is true that mergers can be tricky, but we know they can be managed well and are grateful to you for acknowledging that. 

With that being said, we wish you all the best for your current and future career successes

Arrow Electronics Response
April 21, 2020 – Human Resources Specialist
Thank you so much for your continued service to Arrow, and for your feedback on the organization. Your suggestions are valuable to us as we work to make the employee experience at Arrow even better

review_title: Awesome company to work for, great people and place to gain a solid experience.
pros:
You can learn a lot about the entire industry in pretty short time.
There is no micromanagement, the moment you pick up the knowledge you are free to execute on your ideas and responsibilities, supported by colleges, senior reps/managers if needed. People are supportive, hard working and fun in the same time which makes you want to be a part of the team. If you are keen to grow and learn more they will support you. People who perform well are really appreciated. Flexibility on working from home here and there when needed.
cons:
Workload is sometimes a bit heavy but that probably applies everywhere these days.
Helpfu

review_title: Good for those who want to retire in same company. Safe Job. Good pay (Best in industry)
pros:
1. Good handsome salary, yearly bonus and much more.
2. Safe job, no one will lay you off ever.
3.If you are fortunate enough to get good reporting manager then life is perfect here.
cons:
1. No carrier advancement at all. No growth in terms of knowledge & promotions. Nothing new to learn here, no new training's given. Here people many work at same designations & do same tasks daily literally 6 years or may be even more. But happy because they get handsome salary & safe job.
2.Unfortunately if your reporting manager is not good then you have to slog like slaves because anyways here performance dosent matter you are given chances to improve but company will never lay you off until you resign.
So your manager is god. 
3.Have experienced - Reporting manager was making his reportees feel and make sure there is no "NO" word in your dictionary. if person says NO to voluntary/not compulsory work on Weekly offs he will not pay you yearly bonus for sure & lowest rating he could give (irrespective of your hard work). Its only because managers "ego" was hurted. 
4.Have experienced - Unfortunately the same reporting manager will say NO to you to go home from work even though you get urgent medical emergency call from your family and when your family really needs you. It happened once in my tenure where in i always had clean leave record & good work record.
5.If clarification asked to your HR spoke regarding HR policies, they will not reply to you directly but in turn will check with your manager and the clarification/policies are directed by manager and not HR.
Advice to Management
Make people grow. Give them opportunity to grow, provide trainings to upgrade their skills.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Make people grow. Give them opportunity to grow, provide trainings to upgrade their skills.
